text: Another week has swiftly passed by. Yesterday, as I drove past the new house, I noticed the front window obscured by stacked boxes. The excitement is mounting as we anticipate receiving the keys at closing. Should this week proceed smoothly, we are poised for the closing scheduled for a week from Wednesday. Bethany and I were up watching movies until past 3:00 a.m. last night; it seems we've been indulging in quite a few films recently. To give you an idea, last night included "Thirteen," a film I'd argue is essential viewing for any mother of a teenager—it surpassed my expectations. Following that, we braved "Gigli," which, regrettably, lived up to its poor reviews in the media, but curiosity got the better of us.

Television in the summer was once a wasteland of reruns and unremarkable programming. However, this season is different; two captivating new shows have captured my attention, and for the past week, I've been watching them with great devotion. "Blow Out" presents a paradoxically flamboyant concept in which, surprisingly, not a single gay person appears to be in sight. The show centers on hairstylist Jonathan Antin’s ambitious plan to expand his wildly successful West Hollywood salon by establishing a second outlet in Beverly Hills. Typically, such a venture wouldn't pique my interest—certainly not mine. But as I was channel-surfing, I stumbled upon a scene of Jonathan—both narcissistic and uninspired—surveying an empty storefront on Rodeo Drive. He dramatically declared, in a tone meant for the public, "I am going to build here the greatest salon in the history of the world, ever!" And just like that, I was hooked. Not since the show "The Restaurant" with Rocco DiSpirito have I found such a fascinatingly foolish character to make for such compelling television.

It has been quite a taxing week. I'm currently dealing with tendinitis in my right shoulder, just beneath the shoulder blade. Any extensive movement, especially when using a computer mouse, causes searing pain. As a result, I've had to limit my arm's motion after an intense session updating my website and tending to various online tasks. The strength to draw eludes me now, and the situation is exacerbated by a lack of restful sleep, intensifying my discomfort. My mood is understandably not at its best, yet I remain hopeful for improvement. On a brighter note, my mother's surgery was successful to a degree. She's experienced a partial restoration of her eyesight, now being able to discern fuzzy shapes and differentiate colors, though her vision remains significantly impaired. With optimism, we anticipate a more complete recovery of her sight in the near future.

Today's attempt at doing laundry with the kids in tow swiftly reminded me how quickly the simplest tasks can escalate into complete ordeals. In the midst of this, I discovered the unexpectedly kind nature of complete strangers, who offered help solely out of the goodness of their hearts, with no ulterior motives. Believe me, there was nothing suggestive about my appearance—I was covered in kid slobber and dressed in my most casual 'laundry day' attire. Plus, I'm half-convinced I may never bathe again, so there wasn't even the slightest olfactory allure! At this moment, I'm multitasking: writing this post and simultaneously watching a compilation of No Doubt's music videos. I’m comfortably ensconced at my desk in my room, immersed in both activities.

It's currently 11:14 PM MST, and here I am, seated in my bedroom diligently repairing the personal computer of our Personnel Director from work. I don't necessarily mind the task, but occasionally I ponder the frequency with which I undertake computer repairs as a courtesy for others. While it's rewarding to serve and assist people in this manner, I can't help but question where the boundary should be set to prevent being taken advantage of. Over the past couple of weeks, late-night reading has become routine, and I had been looking forward to turning in early tonight. However, I realized it would be wiser to finish up with this computer repair and return it to its rightful owner. *Laugh* Apparently, there's no rest for the weary. So, amidst my activities, I ended up rewatching Joe Schmo 2 tonight.

Could you remind me of my previous topic? Or shall we delve further into the ongoing "Is this a date?" saga? After our peculiar lunch when my confidence was shaken, I neglected to mention a crucial detail. Before Pat arrived, Dustin began praising him as a great guy who's on the hunt for a girlfriend. As I listened and nodded, a realization dawned on me – we were more engrossed in matchmaking for Dustin's best friend than having the typical small talk over pink lemonade with a near stranger. I excused myself to the restroom, caught my reflection, and posed a silent question: Was I being subtly set up with the other guy? Is this what's unfolding now?

I urge everyone to pause and reflect before taking action. In fact, I would greatly appreciate it if every person would start their day by contemplating their intentions before rising from bed, and endeavor to maintain this thoughtful awareness throughout the day. Should anyone find themselves unwilling to do so, I would prefer they return to bed and enter an indefinite slumber. My patience with foolishness has reached its limit. While I don't claim to be the wisest individual out there, I'm addressing simple matters that require minimal intellectual effort, and hence, I believe it's reasonable to criticize blatant stupidity. I will try to limit this diatribe to a select few types of nonsensical behavior, reserving the rest for a later discussion. Does that sound acceptable? Excellent.

Two issues arise from the scenario depicted in my previous post:  1. While President Bush is indeed attempting to stimulate the economy, his method is flawed. Robert Rubin spoke to NPR's Marketplace earlier and pointed out that the same economic stimulus could have been achieved without accruing long-term debt. How? By implementing targeted, temporary tax cuts aimed at benefiting low and middle-income individuals. The mention of Robert Rubin's name is synonymous with economic acumen for many. Let's try a quick exercise: Can you name a member of the Bush administration's domestic cabinet with the same level of authority as Rubin? Take your time—it might take a while.  2. It's misguided to entrust the Republicans with control during wartime when they have masterfully framed the 'war on terrorism' as a perpetual, global conflict.

Have you ever experienced one of those reflective moments when you ponder the complexities of life? Perhaps you're seated in math class, utterly disengaged, and start to question the inner workings of your brain—how it grasps mathematical concepts. Suddenly, you're struck by the realization of your own existence, there, in that very math class, and you ponder the purpose behind it all. Then, the marvel of existence dawns on you. But just as quickly, it dawns on you that this meandering train of thought is, frankly, quite pathetic. Have you ever had such a moment? I certainly detest it. And do you know what else grates on me? Block schedules. Which mind thought it was a good idea to expect anyone to endure a class lasting two and a half hours? It's blatantly obvious that such prolonged sessions are a form of cruel and unusual punishment.

Despite my reluctance, I prefer to tackle it now rather than attempting to fit it into my schedule during the initial month of my surgery rotation. Arun Shourie highlights that the current Governor of Uttar Pradesh had, as early as 1996, alerted the public to the looming risk of establishing a third Islamic state in the subcontinent. TV Rajeswar, then the chief of the Intelligence Bureau and now serving as the Governor, articulated his concerns through a series of articles in the Hindustan Times. Addressing the credibility of these warnings, Shourie questions: Does the knowledge that these cautions came from him—and not me or Mr. Advani—lend them additional credibility? Or does the mere expression of such concerns lead one to dismiss TV Rajeswar as a concealed communalist, unjustly casting doubt on his suitability to remain in office as the Governor of Uttar Pradesh?

Last night was particularly frustrating. In a moment of despair, I disposed of the sweater I was laboriously knitting after only completing 14 inches. The endeavor not only proved costly—with an approximate loss of $10 for the yarn, priced at $8 per skein—but the execution faltered as I encountered too many stitches at the armholes. Compounding the matter was the mohair yarn, which persistently knotted as I worked, rendering the process of frogging, or undoing the rows, ineffective due to frequent breaks in the yarn. Strikingly, I managed to keep my composure, refraining from swearing, which is uncharacteristic for me. With a somber attitude, I tore at the unraveling knitwork while listening to the second season of "Sex and the City," courtesy of my local library. Eventually, my patience wore thin, and I discarded the entire project. However, despite the setbacks, I recognize that the experience was educational—I certainly gleaned valuable insights from the attempt at crafting this sweater.

During our class last night, we engaged in a lively discussion about the week's assigned reading, "Getting Back into Place: Toward a Renewed Understanding of the Place-World" by Edward S. Casey. The initial chapter introduces the concept of "implacement," and the following chapter transitions into "displacement." In the first chapter, Casey draws a compelling distinction: our modern world and culture are predominantly oriented around time as the defining context—we talk about running out of time, saving time, and being just in time. He argues that placing emphasis on 'place' as the focal point of culture could lead to a more solidly anchored sense of community. (I offer this summary tentatively, as a cautious simplification in case my professor or fellow classmates come across this post.) To date, this is the first piece of literature that has truly captivated me, as if it were reaching out and shaking me by the proverbial shoulders.

This weekend was delightful. I indulged in some leisurely gardening, which had been long overdue, and immersed myself in the music of Nevermore—a decision I wish I had made much sooner. Additionally, I devoted considerable time to reading, completing three books: Bruce Sterling's "Heavy Weather," Larry Niven's "World of Ptavvs," and Octavia Butler's "Parable of the Sower." "Heavy Weather" offered an engaging cyberpunk adventure set in a near-future United States ravaged by global warming and widespread anarchy. The narrative was smart and fast-paced, presenting a thoroughly plausible world. However, I must admit that despite its clever plotting and sharp character delineation, the book did not leave a lasting impression on me. The narrative and characters were well-crafted and strikingly detailed—it's a good book, to be sure, just not an exceptional one in my view.

Fall 1974: I was grappling, for what seemed to be the thirteenth attempt, with the second chapter of my high school algebra textbook. Mathematics was never my forte, and it remains so—I loathe it with a passion, to the point of a genuine phobia. The picture is clear. Amidst this battle of comprehension, the doorbell's chime interrupted me. Setting aside the book, I made my way to the door only to discover no one there. Great. With the interruption brushed aside, I returned to my algebraic struggle, and just as a faint spark of understanding began to dawn in my subconscious, the doorbell sounded once more. In an instant, any hope of a breakthrough vanished. Upon checking, I was met again with emptiness. Nothing is more disheartening for a student already waging a war with math than an unwelcome prankster's antics.

Inevitably, a part of you is eternally etched into my being. Regardless of whether I bore your child, whether we exchanged vows, or whether we were formally acknowledged as a couple, my love for you was profound, resonating within me to this very day. The remnants of the limited, yet intensely intimate, evenings we shared linger in my memory—our hearts and bodies entwined in a deep connection, bathed in the moonlit serenity of a seaside night or sealed with a kiss beneath the rainfall. I feel uneasy about the task of investigative reporting; it strikes me as inherently problematic. To clarify, my discomfort stems from the potential repercussions of the current article I am working on. My lack of conviction possibly contributes to my inability to fully engage with it—to experience its intensity or to summon the necessary passion for questioning. I grew up in a country where asking questions was not only discouraged but dangerous; such inquiries could result in being shot or imprisoned under stringent internal security laws. Consequently, I am unaccustomed to exercising freedom of speech and openly challenging established narratives. Additionally, I acknowledge that I might not be the most amicable person to collaborate with.

Yesterday, my colleagues from the bank and I embarked on an outing to Guintubdan in La Carlota. For many of us, it was a novel experience. The trek to the falls lasted approximately 30 minutes, a brisk walk that left us all breathless, but the effort was worthwhile. Upon arrival, we were greeted by an invigoratingly icy waterfall; the numbing coldness of the water was palpable as we immersed ourselves. Our stay was brief, under an hour, as we ventured forth to explore a nearby waterfall, another half-hour trek. The journey, however, was amply rewarded by the serene allure of the falls—calm, majestic, and undeniably breathtaking. It felt as though we could hear the echo of our own unity with nature. The cold embrace of both air and water was soothing, nearly lulling us into a peaceful slumber.

Some individuals are keen to draw connections, pointing out that the Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe (OSCE) was invited by the State Department to monitor the election. The delegation will comprise members from the OSCE's Office for Democratic Institutions and Human Rights, marking the first occasion that such a monitoring team will be in attendance for a U.S. presidential election. Meanwhile, a group of thirteen Congressional Democrats, which includes four representatives from New York, has urged U.N. Secretary-General Kofi Annan to send international observers to supervise the presidential voting in Florida this year. However, I must express my dissent. According to the information at hand, the OSCE appears to be participating with the intent of learning from the U.S. election process, rather than to supervise it, contradicting the initial, partisan, and impetuous request for U.N. involvement.

The GOP has been criticized for their recruitment tactics after it was revealed that GOP activists pre-registered new citizens as Republicans during naturalization ceremonies in Jacksonville, prompting a relocation of these events. Gary Fineout and Alfonso Chardy report that at a citizenship ceremony in Jacksonville, which saw nearly 200 individuals becoming new Americans, an unusual incident occurred. An immigration official, while directing the swearing-in, encouraged the attendees to visit a voter registration table before departing the June 29th event. Such tables are commonly seen at naturalization ceremonies; however, this one stood out because it was manned by Republican volunteers who had preemptively marked the party affiliation box to enlist the new citizens as GOP members. This raised suspicions for Linda Cross, who witnessed her husband, Dario Cruz, take his oath of citizenship.

The concept of criminalizing that act appealed to me; it might have been a potential escape from being accused and executed for witchcraft. As a non-American blogger, I have been somewhat hesitant to engage in certain discussions, especially those concerning flags. However, since I initiated the topic (of the discussion, not the act of flag-burning), I feel compelled to comment. First and foremost, I believe that enacting a law against flag-burning is absurd. By granting a symbol - any symbol - such unyielding respect and protection, we edge closer to a form of authoritarianism. Symbols are inherently mercurial; they hold no intrinsic meaning. Rather, their significance comes from how they are interpreted or the meanings attributed to them.

Prom is tomorrow and I'm really hoping for a fun time—that's all I want. Rob arrives on May 14th, which is exactly three weeks from today. The thought of it is nerve-wracking to the point where I feel like I'm developing an ulcer. Nonetheless, I'm incredibly excited to see him; admittedly, there's a bit of fear, but I'm mostly thrilled. As of now, I haven't seen the final appearance of my blog. Yet, this seems to be the right place to embark on this journey. While I'm uncertain about the dynamics of what will unfold here—whether I'll embrace it wholeheartedly is still up in the air—I spend a considerable amount of time in front of a computer. So, it makes sense to leverage that time to share the myriad thoughts, albeit somewhat haphazard, that occupy my mind. I'm inspired by a blogger I've never personally met. This individual has mastered the art of keeping readers intimately informed about her daily life while simultaneously providing entertainment.

1. Everyone seems to have a movie or a movie series they're passionate about. For me, it's the Evil Dead series, in case that wasn't clear. I pride myself on possessing one of the most extensive collections of memorabilia from that franchise. 2. Do I play an instrument? Indeed, I do—bass guitar, to be precise—and I absolutely love rocking out on it. 3. My biggest financial indulgence? It's a toss-up between my impulsive purchases of DVDs and the latest tech gadgets. 4. As for phobias, allergies, or compulsive habits, I have none of the first two. However, I do have a particular need to organize the money in my wallet sequentially from lowest to highest denomination at all times.  5. How much wood would a woodchuck chuck if a woodchuck could chuck wood? The answer is straightforward: because I said so.

Hello, I watched "Troy" tonight with my family and came away underwhelmed. Without delving too deeply, as I am quite exhausted, I believe the film had promise. However, it seems an excessive amount of effort was invested in the production design—which was indeed spectacular—at the expense of establishing a cohesive tone and theme. While it retold the mythic tale, it failed to be engaging, and I didn't feel enriched by the experience. The characters were insufficiently developed. Moreover, the score was disappointing, coming across as an uninspired imitation of "Gladiator." In "Gladiator," the haunting vocal soundtrack effectively enhanced a truly compelling story, a synergy that "Troy" sorely lacked.

Today, the absence of my sister weighs heavily on me; it's odd not having her around to playfully annoy me. Her visit may have lasted merely a week, but her impact was deeply positive. As I compile the scrapbook from our recent trip to Tasmania, I'm flooded with warm nostalgia from just last week. The reality that I won't see her for an extended period, with her departure to Bristol in September or October, intensifies my longing. She embodies a cherished connection to my family back home, and I miss them immensely. Tomorrow marks the beginning of a new term, leaving me to wonder how the holidays slipped away so swiftly.

Have you ever had one of those days when you simply can't grasp anything at all? If you haven't, then perhaps it's best to skip the rest of this text, as it may not resonate with you. However, for those who decide to read on, I'd like to offer an observation: sometimes, I wish I had been given a manual. A well-constructed manual, you see, informs you about several key points: the purpose of an object, its abilities, the methods it employs to perform its functions, the outcomes of pressing buttons X or Y, and what actions to take when it fails to operate as expected. It might even include the contact details of an all-knowing guru ready to troubleshoot any issue—undeniably, it's very useful information. Regrettably, no such manual accompanied my arrival into the world.

However, despite the presence of some unique titles, the expansive selection of games at places like CompUSA can become monotonous over time. Initially, I might feel a twinge of envy, but it soon becomes evident that the variety is mostly superficial—akin to different twists on the same genre, whether they be first-person shooters, mystery titles, strategy offerings, or simulations. The profusion of 'Age of Empires' spin-offs is almost farcical: 'AoE' with orcs, 'AoE' with spaceships, 'AoE' with fuzzy wombats! Magic enthusiasts, take heed: Wizards appears to be reluctant to create a quality digital game. At its heart, Magic: The Gathering thrives as a collective experience—a game best savored among friends (or friendly rivals) amidst laughter, playful banter, and the thrill of deploying game-changing moves. Yet, it seems Wizards of the Coast has lost sight of this aspect. Opt to play with friends and you'll find yourself unable to earn gold—a vital in-game currency. The significance of gold is further emphasized by the imposition of a daily limit, which, admittedly, makes sense given that it's the key to unlocking everything within the game. Brace yourself, however, for a tedious and monotonous journey as you grind through 1v1 matches against AI or faceless online opponents, devoid of any real interaction. For those embarking on the free-to-play route, prepare to invest an estimated 4 hours daily for more than a month, in solitary confinement, to acquire the desired cards.

As the third installment in the trilogy, let me address the less favorable aspects upfront. I have a general distaste for prequels as they inherently move backward in the storyline rather than forward, a common issue across the board. Despite this, prequels do enrich the overall narrative. However, the combat mechanics lack the precision and refinement found in Arkham City, resulting in a somewhat sloppy experience. At the time of writing this review (October 26, 2013), there is a significant glitch that halts the completion of a particular side mission—though, fortunately, it does not impact the main story. Additionally, the placement of some gadgets on the keyboard is illogically distant, forcing an awkward stretch across it. This may seem trivial, but it can disrupt the flow of combat and compromise your combo sequence.

The updated version of Shadow Warrior (2013) significantly improves the gaming experience. The boss fights are particularly thrilling and the weapons are satisfyingly responsive - they may not surpass those in Doom (2016), but they are certainly commendable. Additionally, the enemy resilience strikes a good balance, providing challenge without frustration, as long as players effectively manage elemental powers and upgrades. The upgrade system itself is well-calibrated, avoiding any feeling of tedium once familiarized. Ammunition limitations and elemental factors encourage the strategic use of diverse weaponry. The game features an array of distinct and powerful weapons that maintain their utility throughout its duration, setting it apart favorably from games like Borderlands, which rely on a random generation system for weaponry. The soundtrack is another highlight, with a compelling main theme and notable contributions from Stan Bush.

Numerous issues occurred that I'm unsure where to start this review. Everything relates to my career. My player character is a point guard and an outside scorer at 1.71 meters tall, with maximized stats and all the essential perks acquired. However, I'm puzzled as to why shooting ability is linked to a player's height. Why can't someone who is 1.74 meters tall shoot as well as someone who is 1.71 meters? In real life, I'm 1.87 meters tall, and I created my first player to match that height, only to realize that I couldn't achieve a skill level higher than 89. Why is that? It seems like blatant discrimination! Moreover, why doesn't the game inform me of these limitations prior to character creation, or at least when I hit the skill ceiling after weeks of playing?

I believe this iteration of Assassin's Creed has mastered its mechanics in every aspect, from ship battles, sailing, and fishing to parkour. I found myself feeling a stronger connection to the protagonist as well. Although the narrative begins on shaky ground, it significantly improves as the game progresses—a trend I've noticed with other titles in the Assassin's Creed series. Edward makes for a particularly compelling character, and this extends to the supporting cast. The collectibles in this game seem to carry more weight and meaning than in previous installments, possibly due to their enhanced relevance within the game's world. They aren't mandatory to collect, but pursuing them is rewarding, offering well-calibrated incentives.

Although I cannot endorse this game, it's not without its merits. The gunplay is satisfactory if you're willing to invest in firearm components, which leads to my primary critique: the game's reliance on a pay-to-win model. Overlooking this aspect, the gaming experience could be enjoyable, especially with the entertaining hardsuit and the innovative hrv feature. Personally, I'd prefer this game over any Call of Duty installment despite the frustration caused by the microtransaction system. If the pay-to-win approach doesn't deter you, then you might find enjoyment in the game. However, for those who share my aversion to such models, it's best to pass on this one—it simply isn't our cup of tea.

While the game isn't flawless, I've found it immensely enjoyable. The save system, which can lead to frustrating and sudden character deaths, leaves room for improvement. During my first playthrough, I lost my main character around the halfway mark, at approximately 10 hours into a 20-hour game. At that moment, the option to reload a previous save would have been greatly appreciated. To circumvent such devastating setbacks, I've adopted a third-party mod/save tool. Additionally, the aiming reticle could be larger, and the zoom function feels a bit lacking in strength. Nevertheless, I've had a fantastic time with it. I am not usually drawn to zombie games, but the blend of strategic planning, mission-based play, and a first-person shooter/beat 'em up mechanics is brilliantly executed. I find myself seizing every opportunity to play—telling myself just one more mission, one more supply run, or persisting until I've found safety before I even consider closing the game.

An exceptional strategy game! Having played every other wargame in the series—including European Escalation and AirLand Battle—I can confidently state that this title fits perfectly alongside its predecessors. The sheer number of units is impressive, and although I can't specify the exact count, there is a tremendous variety! The graphics are stunningly beautiful, the sound effects are top-notch, and the overall gameplay experience is nothing short of epic. The in-game chat box, accessible from the main menu, provides great entertainment, and I'm not joking. However, be warned: If you think this game is 'easy' or if you're new to the strategy genre, be prepared for a steep learning curve. Do expect to lose many units, but don't get discouraged. Key to success is planning ahead, ensuring solid anti-air and anti-tank defenses.

Initially, I harbored a negative bias toward the game prior to experiencing it myself. The decision to purchase it was met with uncertainty, especially given my skepticism over the concept of portal guns and the use of portals—even as a fan of science fiction. However, I must admit I was thoroughly mistaken. The humor and voice acting throughout the game are nothing short of phenomenal. The clever wit interspersed throughout is often cheesy, but in the best possible way. Each character brings a unique brand of humor, imbued with a distinctive personality that adds depth to the story. As for the level design, it's absolutely stellar. It's worth noting that I've never played the original Portal, but having been captivated by the sequel, I'm making plans to delve into the first installment when time allows. Without a doubt, my experience with the sequel transformed my indifference into a newfound appreciation for the series.

+ Engaging storyline. 
+ Abundant content. 
+ Customizable character; choose any gender you prefer.

- Awkward romance scenes.

Absolutely, this journey through nostalgia is tailor-made for those in their thirties who fondly recall enduring the exasperating Timmy Mallet on British television, just to savor the five-minute Transformers segments. The iconic voice actors behind Optimus Prime, Megatron, Bumblebee, and numerous others have returned, their voices immediately recognizable. The signature transformation sound effect from the cartoons is unmistakably present. Visually, the cel-shaded aesthetic is spot-on, encapsulating the essence of Generation One. Beyond the nostalgic elements, the game is genuinely entertaining. Its combat system is finely tuned, with strategic transformations during battles often being crucial, blending fluidly into the combat sequences — a dynamic departure from High Moon Studios' acclaimed 'War for Cybertron' and 'Fall of Cybertron' titles. Notably, the game leans heavily into melee combat, though certain opponents, such as the Seekers, necessitate a shift to ranged weaponry.

I downloaded the game and gave it a try, but it was rather unremarkable. I found myself spending more time attempting to log in than actually playing. There's a persistent bug where you're notified of an update to the terms of service; however, clicking 'accept' only causes the notification to reappear. Restarting the client seems to resolve this issue. What puzzles me, though, is the requirement to link my Steam and Gface accounts ostensibly for downloadable content (DLC) access. Why is this linkage mandatory? Moreover, this integration is irreversible, leaving me uncomfortable about an unfamiliar company having access to my Steam information. As for the game itself, it's mediocre at best. It's clearly trying to emulate Call of Duty, yet it manages to degrade the quality of gunplay even further. How they achieved this regression is truly baffling.

With the capability to run at 4K resolution at 60fps on a GTX 970, the game offers dual audio options and includes Neptune gear, making it a highly attractive package. Curious? Check it out here: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=nygsb617tmo. This exceptional port serves as a fantastic introduction for newcomers to the series but be aware, it does feature an abundant amount of dialogue, though all of it is optional to engage with. Traditionally, I would recommend using a gamepad for the best experience; however, I found the keyboard and mouse setup to be quite satisfactory as well. Rest assured, both control schemes are fully customizable. The pricing feels appropriate, and I believe it would be a purchase well worth the investment. Players will be pleased to know that more than half the DLC is included at no additional cost, offering a substantial amount of extra content to enjoy. I highly recommend this game to fans of JRPGs, anime, and visual novels, especially to those who are comfortable with extended periods of narrative between gameplay sections.  Enjoy the complete experience without any commentary by following this playlist: https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PLsLFvIJAUpsZeZ9Af395mVNk63xNHsJ1_. Cheers!

From release, I encountered no performance issues, and the game has only improved with subsequent patches. In my opinion, this is an exceptional and entertaining game, albeit the format can be a tad frustrating at times, particularly how the free-roam city area becomes repopulated with new adversaries whenever the story advances. The 'dual play' segments—where one can control both Batman and an additional character—were a highlight for me. Moreover, the flexibility to use a controller for most parts of the game and switch to a mouse and keyboard for tank combat was a welcome feature. Driving the Batmobile through the city is a delight, especially in pursuit of the APC commanders. The experience becomes especially thrilling once you master the brakes to drift around corners, making the drive around the city genuinely exhilarating.

This first-person shooter is exceptional—a definitive standout. Its graphics are striking, its sound design immersive, and gameplay excellent with solid mechanics. It boasts a compelling story, engaging characters, impeccable voice acting, and an electrifying soundtrack. However, it's not for everyone; some cutscenes are notably intense and graphic. While the game's exceptional quality makes minor flaws more noticeable, they are worth mentioning. For instance, the absence of SLI support is baffling; I had to shelf the game until I upgraded from my dual GPU GTX 590 because of subpar performance. Ensure you have a robust single GPU card before diving in. Furthermore, the level design occasionally includes frustratingly insurmountable minor obstacles.

As English is not my native language—I am Dutch—I kindly ask that you overlook any typographical or grammatical mistakes in my review of this exceptional game. I have organized my review into several categories for clarity: graphics, controls, sound, gameplay, and replayability. Regarding graphics, the game adopts a comic-like aesthetic that is strikingly clean and devoid of unnecessary details. The color schemes are pleasing and perfectly suited to the game's style; it is evident that the graphics contribute significantly to the overall experience. Even on high settings, the game does not overtax your system. I run the game seamlessly on my i5 Pentium processor equipped with an NVIDIA GeForce 710M card and 8GB of memory on Windows 8.1. As for controls, the game offers versatility by being playable with both a keyboard and mouse, or with an Xbox controller for those who prefer it.

My extensive playtime clearly indicates how much I enjoy this game. It encapsulates everything I've ever desired from a CoD-style search game. Yet, this shouldn't be mistaken for games like CoD, Battlefield, or other shooters; it's a unique experience that deserves recognition in its own right. I've frequently heard newcomers gripe about how quickly they meet their demise in-game. It's almost as if they're shocked that a headshot could be lethal, which happens to be a realistic outcome.  Since my initial review, I've dedicated more time to the game, investing both time and money. It ranks as one of the top multiplayer games available, an excellent alternative when you're not in the mood for CS:GO.

Two hours into this game and I'm utterly captivated by its humor; it's incredibly funny. Not only does the gameplay impress with its solidity, but the art design is also stunningly beautiful. The music exceeds expectations with its high quality and fitting composition, while the engaging narrative and world-building pique my curiosity. Additionally, the puzzles contribute to the fun. However, it's the comedy that shines as the game's crowning feature. Longtime RPG fans will find themselves chuckling at the clever array of jokes, parodies, and references. Even those new to the RPG genre will be charmed by the game's humor. Fans of classics like Final Fantasy 7 or 10 will find this title a must-play, although I won't spoil the experience. After a solid two-hour session, I had to pause and rest, simply to give my laughter-weary cheeks a respite. So far, this game is an absolute joy.

I sincerely apologize, as I endeavour to support free-to-play titles and independent developers; however, this game failed to meet my expectations. Despite the description resonating with my interests, the game's implementation left me dissatisfied. As an enthusiast of puzzle and exploration games, I unfortunately found the gameplay to be non-intuitive. Even with guidance on how to advance, the gameplay was still unenjoyable. Moreover, the apparent absence of a pause button—essential given the game's timed sequences—strikes me as a glaring omission. Lastly, the game seems disproportionately focused on cutscenes, often leaving me idly tapping my fingers, waiting to engage more actively.

Where do I even begin with this game? It was an absolute masterpiece, captivating me with its stunning graphics and engrossing storyline. The narrative was not just any ordinary tale; I felt as if I were living through the character, eagerly anticipating each twist and turn in the saga they were unveiling. The gameplay was exceptional, and surprisingly, it taught me a great deal about myself—like my newfound fear of heights, which didn't surface until the treacherous ice caverns. Throughout the experience, my anxiety was palpable, but my dedication to Uncle Fred spurred me on. Should you release DLC or a sequel, rest assured I'd be the first in line to purchase and recommend it to all of my friends. My heartfelt thanks go out to everyone involved in crafting this extraordinary game.

Sid Meier's Civilization: Beyond Earth is a turn-based strategy game where players aim to build a civilization that achieves a specific 'victory'. Unlike previous installments set within Earth's historical timeline traversing eras like the Stone Age, Medieval Age, and Modern Age, this iteration propels you into the future with the challenge of colonizing a new planet. I appreciate the fresh approach 2K has taken, introducing innovative mechanics such as the Affinity system and the Orbital layer. However, I find that these new additions can occasionally be overwhelming. An area for potential improvement in the game is the artistic element; incorporating more intricate artwork, especially during the environmental scenes encountered while engaging with other leaders, could enhance the experience.

Outstanding game with immense replay value—it's an incredibly enjoyable zombie survival experience and definitely ranks in my top five all-time favorite zombie games. Upon investing over 60 hours, I can attest to its superiority, particularly in its more 'realistic' approach to the genre. The game is crafted in the vein of classic survival horrors, requiring careful management of resources, such as conserving ammunition and tending to wounds or infections with appropriate medical supplies. The zombies themselves are remarkably natural and well-animated, especially impressive for a free-to-play title. Additionally, I'd recommend teaming up with a friend or two for the best experience; however, the community is exceptionally welcoming, making it easy to connect and communicate with fellow players through chat or voice communication.

On February 7, 2014 - Regrettably, despite the short time I've spent with this game, I cannot wholeheartedly recommend or enjoy it. I'm certain I would be highly engaged if it weren't for two major issues that severely impair the gameplay. Firstly, the absence of Australian servers results in a single red bar causing a significant disadvantage due to intolerable lag. Astonishingly, I experienced stuttering and lag in the offline training mode as well, which is bewildering. Combined with poor ping, these issues completely mar the gaming experience. Secondly, there's an excessive amount of visual distortion - menus, backgrounds, training modes, and in-game graphics are all plagued with artifacts. This is an anomaly I haven't encountered with my graphics card previously. Suspecting it might be an incompatibility with my card’s overclock, I reset my GPU to factory settings, yet disappointingly, it proved ineffective in resolving the problem.

I completed the story late last night. While it may not be particularly deep or compelling, its standout feature is the narrative technique. The game's atmosphere is richly crafted, and the abundance of collectibles effectively enriches the experience. Although I gained considerable insight into Batman's universe, I was somewhat let down by the scarcity of bosses throughout the game. Nevertheless, there are ample opportunities for future installments to address this. The combat strikes an ideal balance of difficulty, tending towards the easier side. Leveling up Batman proved to be underwhelming; however, it's the enhancement and acquisition of gadgets during the campaign that introduce exciting new gameplay dynamics. Successfully reaching areas that were once inaccessible offers a gratifying sense of advancement.

"To the Moon" transcends mere gaming; it is an experience—a profound one that ranks among the best in my life. If you thought Telltale's "The Walking Dead" was heart-wrenching, prepare to be astonished. "To the Moon" eclipses it in emotional depth. I have never felt such a bittersweet mixture of depression and satisfaction over a work of fiction. In my view, this game is the epitome of narrative craftsmanship, accompanied by a soundtrack that is both enchantingly beautiful and flawlessly fitting. Admittedly, the controls can be somewhat cumbersome, and gameplay may not be the highlight, yet the brilliance of the story makes these shortcomings insignificant. What's more, the game's humor is both delightful and respectful, complementing the dignified tone of the narrative without overshadowing it. Furthermore, for fans of "Doctor Who," the references are a delightful, never-ending treat.

"Bastion is an exceptional game, boasting an engaging storyline. Set in the aftermath of a mysterious catastrophe, your mission is to reconstruct a safe haven known as the Bastion. The game offers a wide array of choices, from selecting structures that confer strategic advantages, to choosing an arsenal of weapons and their corresponding enhancements, as well as elixirs that grant various bonuses. Its art style and soundtrack are particularly noteworthy, featuring vibrant colors even amidst post-apocalyptic settings, challenging the notion that the end of the world must be grim. What truly sets Bastion apart is its dynamic narration, which reflects the player's actions in real-time. For instance, if you swap weapons in the armory, the narrator will remark on your choice, making for a tailored storytelling experience."

I initially purchased the game during its early developmental phase, when "spacebux" was the sole in-game currency and a "tech tree" was nonexistent. The game was considerably enjoyable at that stage. All firearms were extraordinarily powerful to the same degree, which eliminated any issues of imbalance; it was a free-for-all where anyone could take down anyone else at any moment. Furthermore, the game granted players unlimited weapon slots and five different loadouts. For a game boasting a plethora of weapons, one would expect to be allotted more than a mere six weapon slots and three loadouts without having to spend extra money. At one stage, I had accumulated roughly three pages of guns and was actively brainstorming new concepts because, to me, that aspect was the most entertaining.

This game proved to be an unexpected delight. All too often, rave reviews overhype products, but in this instance, the enthusiastic critiques accurately capture the entertainment value of this impressive little game. It masterfully blends classic 2D platformer elements with MOBA gameplay, delivering an experience with a unique flair. Contrary to my usual preferences in MOBA games, I found myself drawn to characters I typically overlook. Skeptical at first, I ventured to play as a melee tank and was delightfully surprised by the outcome, which led me to experiment with other characters as they became available through gameplay. The art style and user interface boast an idiosyncratic charm. Consequently, I've adopted one of the game's characters as my avatar and even created a desktop wallpaper from a card set related to the game.

I've recently started playing this game and I'm absolutely hooked. As soon as I slip on my headphones, I'm immersed for hours on end. It's been quite some time since a game has captivated me like this. The music perfectly establishes the ambiance, the sound effects are spot-on, and the controls are flawless. I eagerly anticipate every battle, which have been finely tuned for an excellent combat experience. Initially, I was skeptical about the naval combat system, but it turns out to be thrilling to decimate entire fleets simultaneously! In this game, the only route to defeat is a failure to retreat. If a battle seems too intense, just pull back, regroup, and plan a strategic counterattack. A heartfelt shoutout to the developers for crafting such an outstanding gaming experience!

The reboot of the "Devil May Cry" franchise introduces significant changes, especially for its protagonist, Dante. While long-time fans may feel uneasy about the alterations to their cherished character, this refresh is a positive step forward, as demonstrated by Ninja Theory's new installment. "DMC" provides an ideal starting point for newcomers, delving into the origins of a brash and skeptical Dante and charting his evolution towards altruism. The game skillfully crafts a coherent narrative arc for Dante, elevating him into a mesmerizing character. The story unfolds with Dante's awakening to the corrupt world he once deliberately disregarded.

Where should I begin with this absolutely beautiful game? Its story is extraordinarily charming, brimming with intricate detail, exuding joy through clever puns, endearing dogs, and hidden secrets. The game strikes a perfect balance, embracing seriousness when necessary, yet readily indulging in humor. Character design is impeccable, showcasing a diverse array of personalities, each with their own secrets. This game distinguishes itself from other RPGs by introducing the innovative option to avoid killing anyone—a novel concept in the genre. Drawing ample inspiration from EarthBound, one of the finest RPGs to date, it's evident that this title is something special. Moreover, the soundtrack is exceptional—the best I've encountered in a long time.

I recommend this solely for its free aspect and the potential for a more 'enjoyable' experience for others. In contrast, the 'game' failed to resonate with me. Half the story hinges on shock value, an effect which neither surprised nor moved me emotionally—perhaps due to desensitization or its overly simplistic nature to evoke any reaction from me. The remaining half endeavors to depict the portrait of a person's mental deterioration, exploring themes such as obsession, hallucination, and depression, among others. Although the concept is intriguing, the 'game's' short duration of merely 10 minutes, despite thoroughly engaging with and absorbing every detail provided, lessens its impact.

Is there really a need to articulate the brilliance of Portal? It is a masterful puzzle game that introduces a concept and then steps aside, allowing for an engaging test of intellect that remains thoroughly enjoyable. While not particularly rich in narrative, Portal nonetheless spawned one of the most acclaimed games of 2011. Even now, I find myself returning to it when boredom strikes, relishing the chance to revisit the origins of what has become an iconic title.  Regarding gameplay, Portal’s mechanics are deceptively simple to describe. Players harness the power of portals to navigate complex puzzles, involving buttons that trigger various elements within the game's environment. There are two types of buttons: one requires a direct press, while the other must be weighted down with a cube to activate.

Despite encountering just two bugs—one being minor and the other somewhat bothersome, which have now been resolved, subsequently boosting my frame rate from 60-90 to 80-120—I wholeheartedly recommend this space exploration game. In light of the fact that many reviews focus on technical specifications, here are mine: an i5 6600k (approximately €200), a Radeon RX480 (around €200), a Z170 Pro-Gaming motherboard (close to €150), and 16GB DDR4 RAM (estimated at €70), totaling around €650—a sum that fits comfortably within the medium price bracket, especially given the recency of this setup. With these specs, I enjoy a nearly consistent 60+ fps on high settings, with Vsync enabled. I find it perplexing that 90% of the comments mention having a top-tier setup yet only achieve 20fps.

Do you remember Age of Mythology? It's been quite a while since an RTS game of comparable quality has emerged. Divinity: Dragon Commander nearly rivals the fond status of my personal favorite in the RTS genre. It merges a compelling Risk-like grand strategy layer, and with that combination, it precisely hits the mark for me. I strive to be objective, despite the appealing feature in the game where you can transform into a dragon to support your troops - assisting in attacks and even directing unit production and movement simultaneously. Admittedly, I have a penchant for today's complex RTS games, like Civilization V. These games often aim to integrate intricate mechanics, extensive charts, and multiple resources into a singular, often complex gameplay experience.

Undertale is a game that transcends the sum of its components. The graphics, while solid for a retro-inspired title, and the pleasing soundtrack synergize to create truly stunning and memorable moments. The narrative spans a spectrum of emotional tones, effortlessly blending comedy, drama, heartbreak, and hope – often all at the same time – while cleverly subverting traditional RPG conventions. Yet, I haven't even touched on the richness of its world, the depth of its characters, the intricacies of its story, or the innovation in its gameplay. I could easily fill pages with their details. But for brevity's sake, I'll simply state: whether you're an RPG enthusiast or a general gaming aficionado, Undertale is worth your time. If you can spare seven hours between now and the end of your life, invest it in this game.

If you enjoyed The Witcher 1 and 2, The Witcher 3 is a must-have. Under normal circumstances, I would rate this game a perfect 10/10. Unfortunately, after patch 1.03, it became riddled with bugs and prone to random crashes; thus, frequent saving is highly recommended. Before the 1.03 update, I never experienced a crash, nor did I encounter any bugs from versions 1.00 to 1.03. I've also observed a noticeable degradation in draw distances post-patch 1.03, with objects and even characters popping up abruptly when approached too closely. Regardless, setting aside these technical issues, The Witcher 3 is a truly exceptional game. The developers have invested considerable effort into crafting quests that are both emotionally resonant and profound. There's a wealth of side quests, and the impactful nature of player decisions significantly enhances the experience. Having invested over 50 hours into the game, I am still thoroughly engaged and eager to continue.

I've only owned this game for a few months, yet within that brief period, it has already seen the release of two DLCs. Additionally, various patches have transformed what was a great game into an exceptional experience. The developers are highly engaged with the community, a dedication that is evident across numerous discussion forums and their development diaries. Admittedly, the game has a rather steep learning curve, which I'm still mastering. Nonetheless, the profound strategic depth grants players countless methods to achieve objectives and capitalize on different situations. To me, the game offers almost limitless replayability. I find myself thoroughly immersed in each session I play, regardless of the direction the play-through takes.

Warframe provides an entertaining experience during the initial hours of gameplay. However, beyond these enjoyable moments, the game tends to fall into a pattern of repetitive combat, adversaries, and mechanics. The redeeming factor, though, lies in the developers' dedication; they perform regular updates, enriching the game with substantive content, comprehensive adjustments to systems, additional warframes, and various enhancements. As a casual game, it's decent, but it's unlikely to captivate you for more than a couple of months unless you have a particular affinity for grinding. On the plus side, since Warframe is free, it's worth giving it a shot for those searching for a brief diversion.

This game is exceedingly mundane. I purchased it under the impression that it was the PC counterpart to 'Katamari Damacy,' the engaging and popular PS2 game. Regrettably, it falls significantly short. The premise involves traversing through levels, accumulating increasingly larger objects to expand in size and engulf even larger items. However, the execution is lacking: the gameplay is clunky, the levels lack creativity, and the content resembles a surreal horror tableau that is more dispiriting than entertaining. It evokes a sense of existential dread rather than enjoyment. The portrayal of every 'living' entity, from small pets to humans, is unsettling, making me question whether the game's developers harbored a fascination with taxidermy.

Certainly. Here is the revised paragraph: Let me share my perspective. As someone with a keen interest in politics, the game immediately caught my attention upon discovery. The premise of a simulator charting the journey to the presidency struck me as intriguing—potentially enjoyable, even. However, the experience fell short of expectations. Upon starting the game, you're prompted to choose a political affiliation—Republican or Democrat—without the option for independence or a third-party candidacy. Despite initial disappointment, my optimism prevailed, and I continued exploring the features. I must acknowledge that the game's character customization, while somewhat restricted, does offer a playful element. Amusingly, it is the only time in a campaign where the option to don a hat—or forgo it entirely—is presented.

The story in Fallout 3 was more compelling. The introduction of settlements, although an interesting concept, can become a distraction, often feeling more like a chore than an enhancement to the gaming experience. Certain keybindings are fixed and cannot be customized, which can be frustrating for players. Additionally, the game is riddled with bugs; for instance, I experienced a permanent loss of my Pip-Boy and had to delve into console commands to retrieve it. Moreover, the game dilutes the significance of power armor by making it readily available early on, with ample power cores easily found at trader shops. This undermines the value of power armor compared to previous titles in the Fallout series. While the story is mediocre and the overall quality of the game is unremarkable, it is notable that the game boasts considerable stability—it doesn't crash every ten minutes as Fallout 3 did. In terms of overall quality, is it better than Fallout 3? No. Does it surpass Fallout: New Vegas? Certainly not. Despite the immense hype surrounding its release, the game fails to live up to the lofty expectations set by its predecessors.

At the time of writing this review, my statistics are as follows: I have invested 8.6 hours to complete the game, discovered 10 out of 25 collectibles, and have yet to unlock any of the 15 achievements. What I appreciated:
- The graphics were captivating throughout the game, up until the final level set in the ice caves.
- Although the story is not particularly compelling, the twist after the closing credits somewhat justified the time I invested in playing this game. What I found lacking:
- The visuals in the final level failed to impress me.
- The difficulty spike in the last level led to a frustrating experience characterized by repetitive attempts to succeed.
- The achievements seem excessively challenging, with 13 out of 15 of them being earned by less than 2.1% of players.

Pros:
+ Impressive graphics Cons:
- The game is plagued with bugs. For example, the environment may cause you to get stuck, or your shots might hit invisible barriers even with a clear line of sight on the enemy.
- The game tends to hold the player's hand excessively, leading to a lack of challenge.
- The AI behavior is simplistic, detracting from the realism and strategic aspect.
- Once enemies detect you, they inexplicably always seem to track your location precisely.
- Enemies exhibit inordinately accurate shooting, reminiscent of the frustration experienced in the first Ghost Warrior game.
- Save points and checkpoints are poorly implemented, leading to frustration.
- The storyline is unengaging to the point where I found myself indifferent to its outcome. I cannot recommend this game unless it is deeply discounted by 90%, and even then, playing it feels like a tedious task. I am playing it merely to complete it before moving on to the next game in my library. Reflecting on the time invested in the first Ghost Warrior, which was equally lackluster and provided a sense of relief upon completion, I am unlikely to finish this installment.

Review date: 11/29/2015 – Avoid purchasing this game as the servers are currently offline, rendering it unplayable. Similarly, in Spanish: No adquieras este juego; los servidores están fuera de línea, lo que hace imposible jugarlo. During the brief period when the game was accessible, I found it thoroughly enjoyable. It reminds me of the lyrics from the Steve Miller Band song, which appropriately say, "Go on, take the money and run!" (insert link to the song). After playing the game for 73 minutes: OMG, only an hour into this game and it's incredible! Admittedly, some weapons are overpowered, and the matchmaking can be somewhat unfair. However, it's important to note that in games like Battlefield 3, the matchmaking felt more unbalanced — pitting new players against high-level ones who seemed almost invincible; you could shoot them in the face and it would have no effect!

Who wouldn't be tempted by the charm of donning a fez? In this enchanting puzzle platformer, you'll guide a diminutive protagonist, sporting the iconic hat, on a quest to collect fragments that assemble into cubes. As he traverses an expansive, branching map, the journey promises a delightful experience. While progressing through the game provides a considerable amount of entertainment, pursuing all the cubes and achievements might test your patience. To secure every cube, you must solve intricate codes, some of which can be resolved in moments, while others might tempt you to resort to a guide for help. Admittedly, I succumbed to consulting the 'Complete Guide to Fez!!!' in my own quest for completion.

I can understand why others are drawn to this game, although it didn't quite resonate with me. For starters, I own a Vive and prefer immersive room-scale experiences that utilize the controllers to their fullest potential. Moreover, while the vastness of the game's universe initially filled me with awe, I found that its enormity actually impeded my enjoyment. The steep learning curve and the significant investment of time required to participate in compelling gameplay were overwhelming. Perhaps with greater patience and more time to dedicate to gaming, I might find it appealing. However, lacking both, I opt to invest my time in a broader selection of VR games that are more to my taste.

My all-time favorite first-person shooter is not for the run-and-gun Rambo types. It boasts realistic recoil and ballistics; a single shot to the chest, neck, or head from a rifle-caliber weapon is almost always fatal unless it merely grazes the target. Bullets drop over distance, necessitating short, controlled bursts to maintain accuracy. Ammunition management is crucial—repeatedly reloading mid-magazine will leave you with a collection of half-empty magazines. Endurance is limited; excessive sprinting will degrade your aim as you catch your breath. For improved steadiness, rest your weapon on your elbows in a prone position or against a windowsill. Remember, your accuracy diminishes when shooting standing up.

I would like to clarify that I did not acquire the original "EU" version at its initial release; instead, I purchased it later on discount alongside the expansion "EW," so I fortunately missed the problems others have reported encountering with the game. Despite its challenging nature in the beginning, the game captivated me with its rewarding gameplay dynamics when strategies were successfully executed. Regarding "XCOM 2," I'm thoroughly enjoying it. The game performs quite well on a medium setting on my system, which is equipped with a GTX560 with 2GB of VRAM. Initially, the game automatically set itself to high, leading to slight performance lag, but not to the extent of being unplayable. After adjusting the settings down to medium, the gameplay became much smoother. It might be luck, but I generally don't encounter the issues others seem to experience with games. It appears to me that many of the negative reviews may stem from overly demanding expectations.

This game offers a thrilling experience with its RPG leveling, an extensive selection of ship types, and physics-based movement mechanics for both ships and projectiles/missiles. Its resource management system is straightforward and easy to master, all laced with a touch of dark humor. However, it's not without its drawbacks: the gameplay can become grind-intensive if players don't fully utilize civilian station types; the AI teammates fall short of expectations; and there's a limited variety of equipment and leveling skills, offering no branched pathways. Despite these shortcomings, the game maintains a sense of variety and strategy. It kicks off at a brisk pace and quickly ramps up in intensity. Even with the limited equipment options, there's a continuous sense of progress with new ships to unlock and skills to advance. Modding is the key to truly expanding the game's longevity. Among the modifications available, 'Fight for Universe' stands out as a premier choice, while 'Big Fight for Beef' is also an excellent addition that significantly enhances the gameplay.

Over 2,000 business and political leaders from across the globe are convening at the Swiss mountain resort of Davos for the annual World Economic Forum (WEF). During the five-day conference, they will delve into a variety of topics, from China's burgeoning economic influence to the prospective future of Iraq in the aftermath of this Sunday's elections. Prominent attendees include UK Prime Minister Tony Blair and South African President Thabo Mbeki, who are among the more than 20 heads of state and government leaders present. This year, in contrast to prior ones, the anticipated protests against the WEF are expected to be subdued, as anti-globalization activists have cancelled a demonstration that was previously scheduled for this weekend. Concurrently, the Brazilian city of Porto Alegre is set to host the World Social Forum, an alternative event that intentionally coincides with the WEF's more prestigious gathering in Davos.

The deadline for Fiat and General Motors (GM) to resolve their dispute over a possible acquisition looms, with the cut-off at midnight on February 1st. By this time, Fiat is poised to acquire the option to force a sale of its automotive division to GM, as stipulated in their 2000 alliance agreement. Facing losses in its European operations, GM is keen to avoid taking over Fiat’s faltering car segment. Fiat’s stagnant negotiations have led to a 1.2% decline in its stock value on Tuesday, following a 4% rise on Monday due to speculation of a lucrative settlement. The American automaker is believed to be proposing roughly $2 billion to withdraw from the deal, contending that the agreement was invalidated when Fiat divested its finance branch and diluted GM’s share through a fundraising initiative. This deal originated from a competition between GM and DaimlerChrysler to establish a strategic partnership with Fiat.

Cardinal Cormac Murphy-O'Connor has critiqued the financial toll of the Iraq war, asserting that the billions of pounds devoted to the conflict could have been better spent alleviating poverty. As the leader of the Catholic Church in England and Wales, the Cardinal voiced his perspective on BBC Radio 4 and intends to reaffirm his viewpoint during his Christmas midnight Mass. Utilizing his Christmas message to sharply criticize the Iraq war as a significant misuse of funds, the Cardinal joined with the Archbishop of Canterbury in their public opposition to the conflict. During his appearance on BBC Radio 4's "Thought for the Day," the Cardinal lamented that substantial funds were invested in warfare rather than lifting individuals from "dire poverty, malnutrition, and disease." He has declared 2005 to be a pivotal year for activism, calling for efforts to "make poverty history."

British hopes for major Oscars were dashed as UK talents did not clinch awards in acting and directing categories. Despite receiving three nominations, Mike Leigh's "Vera Drake" missed out on both the director and screenplay accolades, with Imelda Staunton also left unrewarded for her leading role. Kate Winslet was outshone in the Best Actress category by Hilary Swank, while both Clive Owen and Sophie Okonedo were unsuccessful in securing Best Supporting Actor awards. However, the UK's Andrea Arnold triumphed in the Short Film category with her compelling drama "Wasp." Arnold, formerly known for hosting children's TV shows "Number 73" and "Motormouth" in the 1980s, expressed that winning was "totally overwhelming." "Wasp," which portrays the struggles of a single mother scraping by, prevailed over works by her UK fellow nominees Gary McKendry and Ashvin Kumar.

Screenwriter and producer Debra Hill, renowned for her role in creating the 1970s horror classic "Halloween," has passed away in Los Angeles at the age of 54. Succumbing to cancer, Hill co-authored the 1978 landmark film, which featured Jamie Lee Curtis in the iconic role of a babysitter stalked by a menacing psychopath. Under the direction of John Carpenter, "Halloween" grossed over $60 million worldwide, setting a benchmark for independent films at that time. Hill's collaborative efforts with Carpenter extended to other notable works, including "Escape from New York" and "The Fog." A native of New Jersey, Hill's film industry journey began as a production assistant. She swiftly advanced her career, taking on roles as an assistant director and a second-unit director before her fruitful partnership with Carpenter. She was esteemed as a trailblazer in the film industry, assuming roles during the 1970s that were predominantly held by men, and paving the way for future generations of women in cinema.

Broadband is rapidly fueling online engagement, as swift internet access inspires increasing numbers of individuals to share their voices on the web, research indicates. The study by UK think-tank Demos reveals that one in four British broadband users frequently post content and maintain personal websites. The report notes that the always-on, high-speed connections are revolutionizing internet usage habits. Over five million UK households currently have broadband, with the numbers rapidly escalating. Demos' investigation into the effects of broadband on internet behaviors showed that over half of broadband users go online before breakfast, with one in five even confessing to night-time web surfing. More critically, the report suggests that broadband is motivating users to participate more actively in the online sphere.

Russian oil and gas company Yukos is set to return to a U.S. court on Thursday in a determined effort to stay afloat. Currently, the company is being dismantled by Russian authorities to satisfy a massive $27 billion tax debt. Yukos has sought refuge in U.S. bankruptcy protection, aiming to leverage international business law in preventing the compulsory sale of its premier oil production subsidiary, Yuganskneftegas. Despite these efforts, the subsidiary was sold off for $9.4 billion to the state-controlled Rosneft, a transaction that followed an interruption in the state auction. The attorneys representing Yukos contend that this auction breached U.S. bankruptcy regulations. The company, along with its principal investors, has pledged to pursue any entity that acquires its assets through rigorous legal channels.

Voting is now open for the annual Bloggies, which honor the web's finest blogs—digital platforms where individuals share their musings. The nominees were revealed on Sunday, and subsequently, the surge of visitors to the official site was so overwhelming that access had to be temporarily suspended due to excessive traffic. Blogs across thirty distinct categories, which include the Best Regional Blog and the Best-Kept-Secret Blog, are in contention for awards. This past year was significant for the blogosphere; a leading U.S. dictionary even crowned "blog" as the word of the year for 2004. Technorati, a search engine dedicated to blogs, monitors roughly six million of them and reports that over 12,000 new blogs are created daily. Research by the Pew Internet & American Life Project in the U.S. indicates that a new blog springs up every 5.8 seconds. However, they also found that fewer than 40% of these blogs are updated at least once every two months.

The China Three Gorges Project Corporation is reportedly defying a government directive to cease work on one of its significant dam projects, according to Chinese state media. Despite being the constructor of the renowned Three Gorges Dam, the corporation is persisting with construction at the Xiluodu Dam, as reported by The Beijing News. The Xiluodu is among 30 large-scale projects halted by the authorities due to insufficient environmental assessments. Nevertheless, The Beijing News suggests the company might opt to incur a financial penalty rather than halt operations. Additionally, the corporation has disregarded orders to stop work on two other initiatives: the Three Gorges underground power station and the Three Gorges Project electrical supply plant. To date, only 22 of the 30 projects singled out by China's State Environmental Protection Agency (SEPA) for not conducting requisite environmental reviews have adhered to the cessation order.

Manchester United narrowed Chelsea's lead at the top of the Premiership to nine points with a hard-fought win over Manchester City. Wayne Rooney broke the deadlock when he connected with Gary Neville's cross at the near post, directing a low shot that deflected off Richard Dunne and into the goal. Just seven minutes later, Dunne found himself unlucky again, as he inadvertently lobbed a volley over goalkeeper David James, scoring an own goal. Steve McManaman squandered City's prime opportunity, missing wide from three yards out in the first half. During those initial 45 minutes, United appeared unlikely to secure the victory necessary to keep their title hopes alive. Their buildup play was sluggish rather than deliberate, resulting in a solitary opportunity—Paul Scholes' header that sailed over the crossbar.

The new Health Minister for Wales acknowledges that there are valuable lessons to be learned from England in addressing waiting lists. On his inaugural day in office, succeeding the dismissed Jane Hutt, Dr. Brian Gibbons recognized the significant challenges ahead but affirmed the existence of fundamental systems needed for improvement. Opposition parties, including Plaid Cymru and the Liberal Democrats, argue that Dr. Gibbons must implement policy changes to effect progress. Defending her tenure, Ms. Hutt maintained that waiting times and lists represented a mere 10% of the overall health agenda. Prior to his role as the Assembly Member for Aberavon, Dr. Gibbons, who practiced as a GP in Blaengwynfi within the Upper Afan Valley, emphasized the NHS staff's desire for a period of stability following considerable changes and reforms. One of the most pressing issues encountered by Ms. Hutt during her tenure as the first Health Minister of the Assembly was the protracted waiting lists in Wales.

Sir Alex Ferguson, the manager of Manchester United, has commended his team's spirited display following their narrow 1-0 victory at Aston Villa. "That encounter was the most challenging away match we've faced this season, offering a thrilling spectacle of football that was dynamic and featured exceptional passing," the Old Trafford leader reflected. He added, "Our squad demonstrated remarkable resilience and determination, and we were intent on not being defeated. When I consider that match, I note that we've secured a win there, while Arsenal and Chelsea still have their visits pending, and Villa might have their full squad available by then." Ferguson also paid tribute to the veteran influence of Ryan Giggs and Roy Keane, who stepped in from the bench to replace the injured John O'Shea. "Roy's entry introduced a level of calm to our midfield that was essential and unrivaled by any other player," he lauded.

The documentary "A Different Story," which offers an intimate glimpse into the life of celebrated singer George Michael, is slated for exhibition at this year's Berlin Film Festival. Set to feature in the Panorama section, the festival will take place from February 10 to 20. The film provides a platform for Michael to discuss both his professional journey and his private experiences, from the zenith of Wham! to more contemporary occurrences. George Michael is scheduled to present the film at its screening on February 16. Southan Morris, the director, along with executive producer Andy Stephens, will be present at the festival as well. In this 93-minute feature, Michael candidly addresses his formative years with Wham!, his subsequent solo career, his legal confrontations with the record label Sony, and his positions on the Iraq War and U.S. politics.

For the first time, digital music downloads are being counted in the main US singles chart. The iconic Billboard Hot 100 chart now includes sales data from music downloads, expanding its scope beyond what was once a separate download-only chart. Green Day's hit "Boulevard of Broken Dreams" holds the second spot on Billboard's pop chart and leads the digital chart. Later this year, download sales are set to be integrated into the UK singles chart. In the US, digital sales have been instrumental in shaping Billboard's Hot Digital Sales chart. These sales will now be combined with physical single sales and airplay data to formulate the revamped Hot 100 chart. Moreover, Billboard has introduced a second new chart, the Pop 100. This chart also amalgamates airplay, digital, and physical sales metrics, but it specifically sources its airplay data from US radio stations that feature chart music.

The notorious "Spam King," Scott Richter, is pursuing bankruptcy protection as anti-spam laws deal a severe blow to his operations. Richter, the force behind OptInRealBig.com and responsible for a deluge of junk emails, has acknowledged that multiple lawsuits have necessitated the company's move to Chapter 11. Among these legal struggles, a prominent clash with Microsoft stands out, with the tech giant demanding millions in damages. By filing for Chapter 11, OptInRealBig aims not only to address its legal woes but also to continue its business operations. Spamhaus, a leading authority on junk email, ranks OptInRealBig as the world's third-largest spammer. The company was hit with a lawsuit in December 2003 for dispatching emails in defiance of anti-spam regulations. This significant lawsuit was a joint effort by Microsoft and then-New York Attorney General Eliot Spitzer. They accused Richter and his associates of sending billions of spam messages via 514 hijacked internet addresses across 35 countries.

Tottenham's Sporting Director, Frank Arnesen, has refuted claims of a personal dispute leading to Coach Jacques Santini's resignation. Reports had circulated, suggesting that Arnesen's influence at the club had overshadowed Santini, prompting his departure. "It is absolutely not true," Arnesen insisted during an interview with BBC Radio Five Live. "The sole reason for his resignation was his personal issues." Arnesen recounted recent conversations with Santini, noting, "He has clearly stated that the matter is strictly personal." Despite the lingering mystery surrounding Santini's exit after a brief 13-game tenure, Arnesen expressed his inability to provide further insights. "Jacques has never divulged the specifics, but I trust his judgment. We must accept and respect his privacy," he concluded.

Ireland sustained their quest for a Six Nations Grand Slam with a commanding win over Scotland at Murrayfield. Hugo Southwell's early try afforded the Scots an 8-0 lead, yet Ireland gained the upper hand by halftime through tries from locks Malcolm O'Kelly and Paul O'Connell. Denis Hickie added a third try, while Ronan O'Gara contributed 13 points, including a third penalty, to widen the margin. Though Jon Petrie notched a second try for the home team, late efforts by John Hayes and Gavin Duffy clinched the triumph for the visitors. Following two hard-fought away wins, Eddie O'Sullivan's squad looks ahead to hosting England at Lansdowne Road in two weeks' time. Meanwhile, Scotland, under the direction of coach Matt Williams, hopes for a maiden Six Nations victory against Italy in Edinburgh, despite their continued challenge in converting pressure into scores.

Chancellor Gordon Brown has declared that Britain's economic future will be the focal point of Labour's election campaign. His statement followed the final cabinet meeting at Downing Street before the anticipated election call. Brown emphasized that voters will acknowledge Labour's successful track record in delivering stability and growth, a trend he assured would persist. Concurrently, the Conservative Party unveiled strategies to address anti-social "yob culture," while the Liberal Democrats elaborated on their plans to reform the council tax system. In a related development, the Archbishop of Canterbury penned an open letter to all three major parties, cautioning them against exploiting the electorate's fears in their election campaigns. He appealed to the parties to eschew igniting fear among voters about issues such as terrorism, asylum, and crime, as they vie for the upcoming elections.

Ballymena sprinter Paul Brizzel is set to compete at this weekend's AAA's Championships in Sheffield as one of eight Irish athletes eyeing the European Indoor Championships. Alistair Cragg and Mark Carroll, both based in the US, are the only Irish contenders for the Europeans who will not participate in Sheffield. Brizzel aims to retain his 200m title at the British trials. The in-form James McIlroy looks to secure his spot on the British team for Madrid by clinching the 800m title. Having demonstrated exceptional performance on the European circuit recently, McIlroy is among the world's fastest 800m runners this winter and appears to have a definite position for Madrid. Midweek reports confirmed that Cork native Mark Carroll will join Cragg at the European Championships. Currently, Carroll holds the world's third rank in the 3000m, with Cragg at the pinnacle.
