England's rugby union captain, Jason Robinson, is eyeing success in both rugby codes as he leads his team against Australia on Saturday at Twickenham at 2:30 pm GMT. A former rugby league star who switched to union in 2000, Robinson is also keenly interested in the outcome of the Tri-Nations rugby league final, which sees Great Britain challenging Australia at 6:15 pm GMT. Robinson believes that triumphing over the Australians in both matches would represent a remarkable accomplishment, particularly for rugby league. England's rugby union team is poised to clinch their third consecutive autumn international win, following victories over Canada and South Africa, and seeks to avenge the June defeat of 51-15 inflicted by the Wallabies. Simultaneously, a win for Great Britain at Elland Road would break a 34-year streak without a rugby league victory over Australia.

Users are being warned to steer clear of a fraudulent website that purports to raise funds for tsunami victims. The site appears legitimate, mimicking an older version of the official Disasters Emergency Committee (DEC) webpage. However, the DEC confirms it has no affiliation with this counterfeit site and has reported it to the authorities. This site is the latest in a series of scams exploiting the generosity spurred by the tsunami tragedy. The bogus website's link is being distributed through a spam email currently in circulation. The email's subject line is "Urgent Tsunami Earthquake Appeal," and its body is riddled with the poor grammar and frequent spelling errors typical of many phishing schemes.

Iraq is set to open bidding for two telephone licenses with the goal of dramatically expanding nationwide coverage over the coming ten years. The Ministry of Communications in Iraq has called for proposals from domestic, Arab, and international companies. The chosen entities will form partnerships with the Iraqi Telecommunications and Post Company (ITPC) to establish and manage a fixed phone network that will facilitate voice, fax, and internet services. The Ministry aims to elevate Iraq's currently low telephone service penetration rate of approximately 4.5% to around 25% within a decade and seeks to cultivate a dynamic and evolving telecommunications sector. Submission details and tender procedures will be available on the Ministry's website starting February 9. Additionally, an investment roadshow is scheduled to take place in Amman, Jordan.

An increasing number of women and older individuals are actively securing their home computers against cyber threats, as revealed in a study spanning two years. Between 2002 and 2004, the purchase of antivirus, antispam, and antispyware applications by women surged by an annual rate of 11.2%. Conducted by the cybersecurity company Preventon, the research indicates that cybersecurity awareness is spreading among a wide user base. Notably, about 40% of home cybersecurity software purchasers are retirees, with this figure having risen by an average of 13.2% over the last three years. Moreover, retired women account for 53% of these security software buyers, exceeding the number of retired men in this regard. This study reflects the evolving landscape of internet users, challenging conventional stereotypes, and highlights heightened vigilance due to the increased vulnerabilities associated with high-speed broadband internet connections.

Podcasting signals the emergence of DIY radio, with digital music players like the Apple iPod boasting capacities of up to 10,000 songs, a significant amount of storage to utilize. Increasingly, iPod users are allocating this space to content produced by a diverse array of independent creators. This phenomenon, known as podcasting, has found a vocal advocate in the former MTV host and VJ, Adam Curry. Despite its association with the iPod, creating or listening to a podcast requires no specific device. At its core, a podcast is essentially a radio show distributed via the internet, often crafted in the comfort and privacy of one's home with nothing more than a microphone, a computer, and editing software. Once produced, these shows are uploaded online, allowing anyone to download and enjoy them at no cost.

Andrea Levy, winner of the Orange Prize, has now claimed the Whitbread Novel of the Year award for her work "Small Island." As a result, she has emerged as the frontrunner for the coveted Whitbread Book of the Year, having triumphed over Booker Prize laureate Alan Hollinghurst and his novel "The Line of Beauty." Geraldine McCaughrean has also achieved distinction, securing the Children's Fiction Award for the third time with her book "Not the End of the World." All category victors will contend for the Whitbread Book of the Year title and its companion £25,000 prize. A distinguished panel, comprising broadcaster Sir Trevor McDonald, actor Hugh Grant, and author Joanne Harris, is set to convene on January 25th to deliberate and determine the overall winner, with the revelation to follow that same evening. William Hill, the bookmaker, has currently positioned Levy’s London-centric novel as the 6/4 favorite to clinch the title.

Yukos is set to appeal to a U.S. court this Wednesday, seeking punitive measures against Baikal Finance Group, the enigmatic entity that purchased its principal subsidiary. Yukos intends to bring a $20 billion lawsuit against Baikal and other parties involved in the transaction of Yuganskneftegas. Amidst the Russian government’s disregard for a U.S. court injunction issued last week to halt the sale, Yukos' American legal team will push to have Baikal's assets frozen. The origins and intentions of Baikal remain shrouded in mystery. However, Russian media outlets have speculated that there may be a significant connection between Baikal—which acquired the Yuganskneftegas production division for $9.4 billion (261 billion rubles, £4.8 billion) in a government-induced auction held on Sunday—and Surgutneftegas, the country's fourth-largest oil company.

Hearts secured their spot in the Scottish Cup quarter-finals with an assertive 2-1 win over Livingston, establishing their lead with two goals in the opening 10 minutes. Lee Miller broke the deadlock within the first minute by heading the ball from Jamie McAllister's free-kick over Colin Meldrum and into the net. McAllister turned goalscorer for the second, connecting with Saulius Mikoliūnas' cross at the far post to extend the home team's lead and diminish Livingston's hopes. An hour into the match, Craig Easton nodded in a contentious goal, but Hearts maintained their advantage and saw the game through. The first goal sprung from a clumsy foul by Gus Bahoken, who tripped Miller about 35 yards from the goal. McAllister delivered an exquisite free-kick into the Livingston area, where Miller rose above the passive defence and looped his header from close range over Meldrum. The team's lead was solidified at the 10-minute mark when Mikoliūnas dashed down the right flank and whipped in a cross to the back post. There, McAllister made a timely arrival to power a header past the Livingston goalkeeper.

Sun Microsystems has introduced a pay-as-you-go service that enables customers in need of substantial computing power to rent it on an hourly basis. This service, known as Sun Grid, charges users $1 (53p) for one hour of processing and storage capabilities on Sun-maintained systems. The concept of grid computing, a term gaining popularity within the company, posits that computing capacity should be considered a vital resource, akin to hardware and software. Sun has drawn parallels between grid computing and the evolution of electricity, suggesting that the system may evolve similarly to how essential utilities like electricity and water have. During a webcast at Sun's quarterly Network Computing event in California, Chief Operating Officer Jonathan Schwartz highlighted the efficiency of this model by posing the question, "Why build your own grid when you can use ours for a buck an hour?"

Scotland's Justice Minister, Jamieson, has issued a stern warning to bigoted soccer fans, expressing her intent to impose bans to prevent them from attending matches, thus affecting them "where it hurts most". Cathy Jamieson elaborated that exclusion orders are among a number of strategies that the Scottish Executive is contemplating in its campaign to confront sectarianism. She commended both Celtic and Rangers for their efforts in addressing this issue. Nevertheless, Jamieson highlighted that eradicating the sectarian abuse prevalent at Old Firm matches remains a crucial goal. The minister's comments came in the run-up to the anticipated third-round Scottish Cup game between the Glasgow rivals at Parkhead on Sunday. Tackling the enduring sectarianism among some supporters of both teams has emerged as a prominent objective for the Executive. In efforts to advance this initiative, Jamieson, accompanied by First Minister Jack McConnell, met with supporters' groups from both sides last week to deliberate on the matter.

The Hollywood film "Beyond the Sea", featuring Kevin Spacey and Kate Bosworth, made its UK debut at London’s Leicester Square last Thursday. Spacey, at 45, not only wrote and directed the film but also took on the lead role, embodying the iconic 1950s singer Bobby Darin. "This is my tribute to someone I consider an extraordinary talent," remarked Spacey, who personally delivered all 18 songs in the movie’s soundtrack as Darin. Bosworth, aged 21, portrays Darin’s wife, the actual Hollywood starlet Sandra Dee. "Before this project, I was completely unfamiliar with Bobby Darin, but I've since become an avid admirer," Bosworth confessed at the event, which she graced alongside her British significant other, Orlando Bloom.

On Friday, Leeds will face Saracens at Headingley, with the match scheduled to start at 2000 GMT on 25 February. The Tykes have strengthened their squad by securing the services of prop Ed Kalman from Newcastle and Tom McGee from the Borders on a loan basis. They have also welcomed the addition of fly-half Craig McMullen from Narbonne. Saracens, meanwhile, have made four alterations to their lineup, with Raphael Ibanez stepping in as hooker, Simon Raiwalui and Ben Russell joining the pack, and Kevin Sorrell taking the position of outside centre. The Headingley encounter was confirmed for Friday after the pitch successfully passed an inspection earlier in the day. The Leeds team has been announced as follows: Balshaw; Rees, Christophers, Bell, Doherty; McMullen, Dickens; McGee, Rawlinson, Gerber; Murphy, Palmer (capt), Morgan, Parks, Popham. The bench comprises replacements: Kalman, Regan, Hyde, Rigney, McMillan, Rock, and Vickerman.

The future of landline phones appears uncertain as the ubiquitous fixed-line home phone may soon become a rarity. According to Nokia's research, an increasing number of individuals rely exclusively on their mobile phones for all incoming and outgoing calls. The study reveals that in the UK, Germany, the US, and South Korea, over 45 million people have transitioned to mobile-only communication. While lower call charges have sustained the use of landlines, a significant portion of respondents believe mobile technology represents the definitive future. The research, sponsored by Nokia, indicates that mobile phones and landlines serve distinct roles; landlines are preferred for lengthy conversations, whereas mobiles are favored for shorter, more transient exchanges, particularly between friends and on-the-go. In the UK, a notable 69% of participants cited cost-effectiveness as the primary reason for using landlines over mobile phones.

In the SAP Open quarterfinals, second-seed Andre Agassi was strikingly outplayed by Jurgen Melzer, succumbing to a decisive 6-3, 6-1 defeat. Melzer's cunning drop shots left Agassi confounded throughout the match in San Jose. Meanwhile, the defending champion and number one seed, Andy Roddick, made a determined comeback to edge out Sweden's Thomas Enqvist in a tightly contested match, 3-6, 7-6 (8-6), 7-5. In other tournament upsets, Cyril Saulnier, an unseeded player, dispatched fourth seed Vincent Spadea with a straightforward 6-2, 6-4 victory, while Tommy Haas emerged victorious against eighth seed Max Mirnyi in a grueling duel, 6-7 (2-7), 7-6 (7-3), 6-2. With this win, Melzer has now claimed victory in two of his three encounters with Agassi. Melzer remarked on his performance, "I had a solid game plan and executed it perfectly. Facing Andre is always challenging. I aimed to disrupt his rhythm and prevent him from dictating the game, as he's known to make his opponents relentlessly chase the ball."

A coalition of MPs has heightened pressure on Prime Minister Tony Blair regarding House of Lords reform by releasing a comprehensive proposal for transformation. This bipartisan group has introduced a draft bill that recommends a more compact second chamber where 70% of the members would be elected. Attempts to agree on reforms have been unsuccessful since 1999 when 600 hereditary peers were ousted. However, the coalition is confident it can garner support for the expulsion of the remaining 92 hereditary members. Although the government delayed plans to evict the remaining hereditary peers citing anticipated opposition within the Lords, Tony Blair has insisted that a consensus on reforms is necessary. Furthermore, there are indications that the Labour Party's manifesto might include suggestions for altering at least the powers of the Lords.

Allan Scott is poised for medal contention at the upcoming European Indoor Championships, buoyed by a promising international debut. The young Scotsman, hailing from East Kilbride, placed fourth in the 60m hurdles at the José M Cagigal memorial meet in Madrid. Despite finishing just shy of the podium, Scott remains upbeat, acknowledging the experience as a valuable learning opportunity. "It was definitely a learning curve, and challenging for a medal next week is certainly within reach," he stated. At the Madrid event, the victory went to Felipe Vivancos who matched the Spanish national record. The competition saw Sweden's Robert Kronberg taking silver, and Haiti's Dudley Dorival securing bronze. Although Scott secured a win in his heat with a time of 7.64 seconds, a marginal slowdown by 0.04 seconds in the final of his first IAAF Indoor Grand Prix circuit occasion left him slightly disillusioned. However, his performance holds promise for future success on the circuit.

A woman from the United States has filed a lawsuit against Hewlett Packard (HP), alleging that the company has programmed its printer ink cartridges to expire after a set date. Hailing from Georgia, the woman contends that a chip within the cartridge misleads the printer into indicating a refill is necessary even when there is sufficient ink remaining. The legal action aims to encompass all individuals in the United States who have purchased HP inkjet printers since February 2001. HP, which holds the title of the largest printer manufacturer globally, has chosen not to issue a statement regarding the lawsuit. While HP's ink cartridges employ chip technology to monitor and notify users of low ink levels, the lawsuit alleges that the chips are designed to disable the cartridges on a specified date, irrespective of whether the ink has been depleted.

Virgin Radio is set to become the first station globally to offer radio broadcasts through 3G mobile networks. In collaboration with the technology company Sydus, Virgin Radio will stream its content over select 2G and advanced 3G networks. Later in the year, listeners will have the opportunity to download a software application from Virgin Radio's website, which will activate this feature. James Cridland, Virgin Radio's Head of New Media, believes this initiative positions radio at the core of the 3G revolution. The pioneering service will debut with Virgin Radio, and will soon expand to include Virgin Radio Classic Rock and Virgin Radio Groove. Mr. Cridland emphasized the convenience of this technology, stating, "With this app, listeners can enjoy Virgin Radio anywhere, using just the phone they carry in their pocket."

Roxy Music is set to perform at the Isle of Wight Music Festival this June, sharing the lineup with acts such as Morrissey, Supergrass, and Idlewild. R.E.M. has already been confirmed as the headlining act for the festival, which will span from June 10 to June 12. Original Roxy Music members Bryan Ferry, Phil Manzanera, Andy Mackay, and Paul Thompson will reunite for a performance on Saturday night. Additionally, the band is currently in the studio crafting new music, marking their first fresh material since the 1982 release of 'Avalon.' Roxy Music was established in 1971 by Ferry, Mackay, and Brian Eno, with Manzanera joining in the subsequent year. They achieved their first chart success with "Virginia Plain" in 1972, followed by other hits such as "Street Life," "Love Is the Drug," and a cover of John Lennon's "Jealous Guy" in 1981.

Ireland's Brian O'Driscoll is among the four Six Nations captains joining the Northern Hemisphere squad for the IRB Rugby Aid match on March 5. He is set alongside France's Fabien Pelous, Scotland's Gordon Bulloch, and Italy's Marco Bortolami in the distinguished team. The Northern team will be coached by Sir Clive Woodward and will face the Southern Hemisphere team, led by Rod MacQueen, in a tsunami fundraising match at Twickenham. "I'm looking forward to working with such outstanding players," Woodward commented. This event offers Woodward an opportunity to evaluate his selections ahead of announcing his British and Irish Lions touring party, scheduled to visit New Zealand in the summer. "The game is set to be a fantastic spectacle," he added.

The comedy "Sideways" swept this year's Independent Spirit Awards, clinching all six categories it was nominated for, including Best Film. Alexander Payne garnered the awards for Best Director and Best Screenplay, sharing the latter with co-writer Jim Taylor. The film's lead actors, Paul Giamatti, Thomas Haden Church, and Virginia Madsen, each took home acting honors. With five Oscar nominations, "Sideways" is anticipated to perform strongly at the upcoming Academy Awards on Sunday. Celebrating its 20th anniversary, the Independent Spirit Awards are dedicated to recognizing achievements in films produced outside the major studio system and traditionally precede the Oscars by one day. In other recognitions, Catalina Sandino Moreno won Best Actress for her portrayal of a drug smuggler in "Maria Full of Grace," a role that also earned her an Oscar nomination. The award for Best First Screenplay was also secured by "Maria Full of Grace" writer Joshua Marston.

Prince was crowned the 'top music earner' of 2004, surpassing other pop stars like Madonna and Elton John on Rolling Stone magazine's annual list. In total, the singer amassed $56.5 million (equivalent to £30.4 million) through concert revenue, album sales, and publishing. His successful Musicology tour and corresponding album were significant contributors to his earnings, keeping Madonna in second place with her income of $54.9 million (£29.5m) from her worldwide Re-Invention tour. Simon and Garfunkel landed in the 10th spot, as their comeback tour enabled them to rake in $24.9 million (£13.4m). Rolling Stone highlighted Prince's triumph, stating, "Prince returned to center stage after a decade in the commercial wilderness." His 2004 Musicology tour grossed $90.3 million (£48.5m) in ticket sales, and the Musicology album itself sold 1.9 million copies.

Irish rockers U2 were honored at France's prestigious NRJ Music Awards, yet they were surpassed by the boy band Blue for the top prize. While U2 was celebrated with a special achievement award, Blue clinched the award for Best International Group. American group Maroon 5 emerged as the Best New International Artist and also secured the Best International Song accolade for their hit "This Love." The awards were determined by over five million radio listeners who cast their votes. Meanwhile, Usher and Avril Lavigne were awarded the International Male and Female Artist prizes, respectively. At the Cannes award ceremony, U2's lead singer Bono, while receiving the award from model Naomi Campbell, expressed his fondness for the region in French, saying, "Although I am not from this country, I must confess that it is here on the Côte d'Azur that I feel most at home."

Wal-Mart is countering its detractors as two prominent American corporations launch advertising campaigns aimed at correcting misconceptions about their products and business practices. The world's largest retailer, Wal-Mart, has placed more than 100 full-page ads in national newspapers. The company is actively addressing criticism regarding its pay scales, benefit packages, and promotional tactics. Concurrently, pharmaceutical giant Eli Lilly is preparing to tackle misleading assertions concerning its antidepressant, Prozac. Initiating the defense, Wal-Mart introduced the campaign with ads in prominent outlets such as The Wall Street Journal, featuring an open letter from its President Lee Scott. He emphasized the necessity for the public to receive the "unfiltered truth," stating, "There are numerous 'urban legends' circulating about Wal-Mart, but facts remain facts."

The Conservative party has proposed a new policy where local communities would elect their own police commissioners. This initiative, announced by party leader Michael Howard, aims to replace the current "inconspicuous" police authorities. Howard clarified that this position would not encroach upon the chief constable's responsibilities. However, the Liberal Democrats have expressed concerns that such a plan might enable extremist groups to influence local policing. Labour has also voiced skepticism, labeling the Conservative's promises on policing as "extravagant." In reaction to the proposition, the Police Federation of England and Wales' chairman, representing front-line officers, emphasized the importance of maintaining operational independence. Jan Berry commented, "Policing is a service; it should not be treated as a political plaything subject to the whims of election cycles. These proposals could lead to those with radical political ideologies shaping enforcement on the streets," she cautioned.

At a glance: The UK Conservative Party has proposed a policy to conduct health screenings for immigrants in the event they secure victory in the general election. Here is a brief outline of the plan: individuals intending to reside and work in the UK from non-EU countries will be subject to these checks. Specifically, those planning a stay of six months or longer from countries with high tuberculosis (TB) rates will be mandated to undergo a chest x-ray, along with additional tests if deemed necessary. Moreover, any person arriving from outside the European Union and wishing to remain for over a year will be required to complete a comprehensive medical examination, including screenings for TB, hepatitis B, and HIV. A positive TB result will lead to an automatic denial of the visa application. Cases concerning other health conditions will be evaluated individually.

The promise of Paris has ignited Welsh hopes, sparking the question: has there ever been a more thrilling Six Nations match than the recent Saturday epic in the French capital? Moreover, can Wales sustain this resurgence and achieve their first Grand Slam since 1978? These questions are on the minds of not only Welsh supporters but rugby enthusiasts everywhere, following Wales' electrifying performance in Paris. Welsh rugby icon Mervyn Davies, who was part of the 1970s teams that secured two Grand Slams, lauded the recent match as "one of the greatest displays in the last thirty years." Martyn Williams, who scored two tries for Wales that day, described the encounter as "one of the most surreal experiences of my career." Overcome with disappointment, French coach Bernard Laporte succinctly characterized the game by stating, "The match was a tale of two halves: a French one and a Welsh one."

The Manchester rock band Doves has soared to the top of the UK album chart with their latest release, "Some Cities," debuting at number one. They have dethroned the flamboyant U.S. act Scissor Sisters. Their album comes on the heels of their single "Black and White Town," which peaked at number six. Meanwhile, R&B sensation Nelly clinches the number one spot on the singles chart with "Over and Over," a collaboration with Tim McGraw. Chart newcomers include Girl Aloud, Akon, and Kaiser Chiefs, joining Futureheads and Usher in the top ten. The latest re-release from Elvis Presley, "(Marie's the Name) His Latest Flame," has made an impressive entrance at number three, just a notch above Girls Aloud's "Wake Me Up." Akon holds strong with "Locked Up" at number five, and the Leeds band Kaiser Chiefs secures their second hit with "Oh My God" at number six.

Wales hooker Mefin Davies appears set to continue his tenure with English club Gloucester, despite the Neath-Swansea Ospreys showing interest. BBC Wales reports that the Ospreys are eyeing the 32-year-old, yet his preference is to remain at his current club. As one of the standout players in Saturday's RBS Six Nations victory over England, Davies is in the midst of a one-year contract at Kingsholm. However, his contributions to the Zurich Premiership team have been significant, and he is expected to be offered a new contract for the next season. Following the disbandment of the Celtic Warriors region last summer, Davies found himself without a team and subsequently accepted a semi-professional contract with Neath RFC. While he gained playing time with the Ospreys upon the request of the Wales management, Davies confessed that prior to his Gloucester move, he was disgruntled with the handling of his situation.

Minister for Local Government Nick Raynsford has acknowledged the dissatisfaction among cabinet members regarding the proposal to reallocate Whitehall funds to suppress council tax increases. Chancellor Gordon Brown shifted £512 million from central government to local authorities in his Pre-Budget Report announced on Thursday. Raynsford revealed that he engaged in some "pretty frank discussions" with his fellow ministers about these plans. Nevertheless, he emphasized the necessity for local governments to provide quality services without resorting to significant hikes in council tax. This injection of central government funds forms part of a complete £1 billion package aimed at assisting English local authorities in maintaining council tax increases below 5% for the following year, coinciding with what is anticipated to be an election year. Raynsford also mentioned that almost every central government department has a vested interest in efficiently managed local governments.

Israeli club Hapoel Bnei Sakhnin, which has recently enlisted four African players, including Zimbabwean goalkeeper Energy Murambadoro, is set to compete in the UEFA Cup. Bnei Sakhnin holds the distinction of being the first Arab team to participate in European competition and is poised to face English Premiership team Newcastle United in the opening round. Goalkeeper Murambadoro, who gained recognition at the African Nations Cup finals in Tunisia, was instrumental in the team's 6-1 victory over Albania's Partizani Tirana in the prior round. After a short tenure with South African club Hellenic, Murambadoro made his move to Israel. Having clinched the Israeli Cup final last season, the club is situated in Sakhnin, in close proximity to Haifa. Renowned for their strong values, Hapoel Bnei Sakhnin actively promotes peace and cooperation within Israel.

A new report suggests that reducing the drink-drive limit by a third could save even more lives than previously estimated. Research conducted by University College London posits that lowering the limit from 80mg to 50mg of alcohol per 100ml of blood has the potential to prevent 65 fatalities annually. These findings are set to be released by the Parliamentary Advisory Council for Transport Safety at a time when MPs prepare to vote on the government's road safety bill—a bill which proposes alterations to speeding penalties but leaves the drink-drive limit unchanged. Professor Richard Allsop, a transport specialist, conducted the study and found that such a reduction in the limit could result in 230 fewer serious injuries on Britain's roads compared to figures from 2003, and could provide an economic benefit of £119m yearly. This projection surpasses a previous estimate from a 1998 Department of Transport report, which calculated that a similar reduction might save 50 lives per year.

This paper introduces a millimeter-scale CMOS 64×64 single charged particle radiation detector system tailored for external beam cancer radiotherapy. Utilizing a 1×1 µm² diode, the device quantifies the energy imparted by individual charged particles within the depletion zone, while the array's design ensures an expansive detection surface of 512×512 µm². Conventional voltage-drop sensing methods give way to the system's novel approach of measuring pulse width—specifically, the duration for voltage to reset to its baseline—eliminating the dependency on energy-intensive and sizeable analog-to-digital converters. The prototype ASIC, produced using TSMC's 65 nm LP CMOS process, demonstrates a low average static power consumption of 0.535 mW with a 1.2 V analog and digital power supply. Clinical testing with a 67.5 MeV proton beam confirms the system's overall functionality.

The capacity for autonomous vehicles (AVs) to adhere to externally directed routing has been demonstrated to mitigate the detrimental effects of individualistic routing decisions on network throughput. Nevertheless, it is overly optimistic to presume that AVs would willingly submit to the control of a centralized entity. In our paper, we introduce a dual strategy, integrating routing and pricing controls, designed to entice AVs into adhering to centrally managed, system-optimal (SO) routes through toll discounts, while AVs driven by user equilibrium (UE) preferences and human-operated vehicles (HVs) face a surcharge for congestion. This issue is approached through a bi-level optimization framework; in the upper level, dynamic toll rates are calibrated, and in the lower level, we simulate a dynamic traffic assignment incorporating a diverse mix of AVs and HVs.

Optomechanics and electromechanics have enabled the preparation of macroscopic mechanical oscillators in their quantum ground states, as well as in quadrature squeezed and entangled states of motion. This advancement has not only made it possible to coax increasingly larger objects into the quantum realm but has also spurred interest in employing mechanical oscillators for quantum information processing and communication, and as precision force sensors that surpass the standard quantum limit. However, the primarily linear interaction between motion and light or electricity limits access to a wider spectrum of quantum states of motion, such as cat states or energy squeezed states. Early optomechanical proposals recognized that creating a strong quadratic coupling of motion to light could overcome this limitation. Despite experimental demonstrations of systems with quadratically coupled optomechanics, these systems have yet to realize nonclassical states of motion.

Online reviews serve as valuable guides for consumers looking to make informed purchasing decisions. However, these evaluations are susceptible to manipulation through the use of counterfeit reviews, commonly known as "spam," crafted by adept spammers. These spammers are becoming increasingly cunning, honing their techniques to evade detection. Identifying these spammers is particularly challenging due to the rapid evolution of their strategies, the variety of approaches used across different spammers and products, and the typically clandestine nature of their methods. Moreover, most current detection systems prioritize accuracy over preserving the integrity of the product evaluations. To overcome these obstacles, we have developed a minimax game in which spammers and spam detectors vie against one another, with their objectives extending beyond mere detection accuracy. The establishment of Nash equilibria in this game results in robust detectors that are impervious to an array of spamming tactics.

We have engineered single-shot shaped pulses explicitly designed to achieve ultra-high-fidelity (uh-fidelity) population transfer within a three-level quantum system arranged in a lambda configuration. To guarantee this high fidelity, we employed the Lewis-Riesenfeld (LR) method to extract a set of precise solutions that accomplish an exact transfer, adhering to a singular dynamical mode of the LR invariant. Within this set, we pinpoint a tracking solution characterized by a single adjustable parameter that concurrently regulates the fidelity of the transfer, the population of the excited state, and the robustness. Robustness in an uh-fidelity transfer is quantified as the minimal percentage deviation in pulse areas that causes the infidelity to exceed $10^{-4}$. Our analysis revealed that the robustness of the shaped pulses we developed surpasses that of both Gaussian and adiabatically optimized pulses, particularly for moderate pulse areas.

In this study, we examine the configuration of the population negative log-likelihood function in Gaussian mixture models with varying component numbers. The nonconvex nature of the function results in numerous local minima, which are suboptimal even with well-separated mixtures. We demonstrate that these local minima possess a consistent structural pattern, revealing the true mixture's component centers. Specifically, each local minimum reflects a unique amalgamation of fitting multiple Gaussians to a single true component and fitting one Gaussian to several true components. Our findings are applicable under the condition that the true mixture components maintain a minimum separation and remain relevant regardless of whether the model contains too many or too few components. When examining Gaussian mixtures of three components, we achieve more precise outcomes correlated with the separation distance between these components.

We examine the relationship between two approaches to constructing the mirror partner of a Calabi-Yau orbifold, defined as the quotient of a hypersurface, denoted $x_m$, within weighted projective space by a suitable subgroup $g$ corresponding to phase symmetries, and described by a quasi-homogeneous polynomial $w_m$. The first approach, known as the Berglund-Hübsch-Krawitz (BHK) construction, utilizes an alternate weighted projective space and constructs the mirror through the quotient of a new hypersurface $x_{m^t}$ by a dual group $g^t$. The second method, the Batyrev construction, generates the mirror partner as a hypersurface within a toric variety, which is specified by the reflexive polytope that is dual to the polytope associated with the original Calabi-Yau orbifold. We present cogent evidence supporting the equivalence of these two methods.

This study presents an expansion of the investigations into human gait by adapting existing models from the literature, specifically those of Keller and Kockshenev, into a composite model. This novel hybrid model integrates a strategy for minimizing metabolic energy during a race alongside a nonlinear portrayal of the mass center's oscillatory movement, aiming to accurately simulate the walk-run transition. The analysis of experimental data across varying speed regimes suggests that the perimeter of the mass center's trajectory is a significant metric in evaluating this dynamic. Furthermore, to validate the model, an experimental protocol was established in conjunction with the Biomedical Engineering Research Group, and the basic science and laboratory facilities at the Universidad Manuela Beltran in Bogotá, Colombia.

We introduce a novel mixed variable symplectic (MVS) integrator specifically designed for planetary systems that efficiently manages close encounters. This method utilizes time regularization to maintain the stability characteristics inherent to symplectic integrators, while dynamically adjusting the effective step size during planetary encounters. Our high-order MVS approach enables integration at large time steps when planets are distantly separated, thereby optimizing computational efficiency. The algorithm proves capable of resolving near-exact collisions—with mutual separations as minute as a fraction of the planets' physical radii—without altering the time step used for more stable configurations, such as within the solar system. We examine the algorithm's long-term stability in simulations of six super-Earths undergoing significant scattering over 50,000 years. Furthermore, we benchmark our algorithm against hybrid methods like Mercury, demonstrating superior energy conservation at a comparable computational cost.

Entanglement serves as a vital resource for quantum information processing. To detect entanglement, a common tool used is the entanglement witness, which involves measuring a witness operator. This measurement is designed to produce positive results for all separable states and may yield negative results for particular entangled states. However, practically speaking, the construction of an efficient entanglement witness becomes exceedingly challenging as the dimension of the Hilbert space grows exponentially with the size of the system. Considering $n$-partite Greenberger-Horne-Zeilinger (GHZ)-like states, the most robust witnessing strategy necessitates $n+1$ local measurement settings and is capable of tolerating up to 50% white noise. In contrast, the most efficient method for GHZ-like states requires merely two local measurement settings and can withstand up to 33% white noise.

In the context of general relativity, the Kerr spacetime stands as the definitive stationary solution for an isolated black hole, characterized by a distinctive multipolar structure that hinges solely on its mass and angular momentum. We have developed a robust method to deduce the multipole moments from a range of stationary spacetimes, which we have applied to an extensive set of horizonless microstate geometries. These geometries diverge from the Kerr metric's axial and equatorial symmetry, presenting a significantly more complex multipolar structure. This complexity offers a means to phenomenologically constrain fuzzball models. Our numerical analyses suggest that the absolute values of all multipole moments are typically greater than those of a Kerr black hole with equivalent mass and angular momentum. Present-day observations of black hole candidates' quadrupole moments impose only modest restrictions on fuzzball theories. However, prospective gravitational-wave observations from the space-borne mission LISA, concerning extreme mass-ratio inspirals, are anticipated to enhance these limits substantially.

Analyzing time-evolving graphs presents significant challenges across various fields, including bioinformatics, physics, and social network analysis. Typically, these graphs feature edges representing brief interactions, such as messages, as well as more sustained structural relationships, like friendships. Often, humans define these long-term connections, which can be both costly to generate and less than ideal for subsequent tasks. To address these drawbacks, we introduce a model that merges temporal point processes with variational autoencoders. This model is adept at discerning temporal attention among nodes by monitoring their communication patterns. By leveraging the dynamics of node interactions to learn crucial features of temporal attention, our approach enhances flexibility and circumvents the limitations inherent in human-defined edges.

We report observations of thermally induced transverse vibrations in a photonic crystal waveguide (PCW). The PCW is composed of two parallel nanobeams separated by a 240 nm vacuum gap. We have developed and confirmed models for the conversion of the nanobeam motion into phase and amplitude modulation of a weak optical probe traveling in a guided mode (GM) of the PCW, both at frequencies distant from and close to the dielectric band edge. Given that the PCW is tailored for near-field atom trapping, our study lays the groundwork for assessing the potential adverse impacts of thermal motion on optical atomic traps in close proximity to PCW surfaces. Our longer-term objectives include establishing robust, atom-mediated connections between individual phonons of vibration and single photons in the GMs of the PCW. This paves the way for quantum-level optomechanics that involves atoms, photons, and phonons.

We have established natural splittings for the values of global Mackey functors at orthogonal, unitary, and symplectic groups. Specifically, the restriction homomorphisms connecting orthogonal, unitary, and symplectic groups in consecutive dimensions are naturally split epimorphisms. Such splittings garner interest due to their implications in equivariant stable homotopy theory. Within this theory, the equivariant stable homotopy groups of any global spectrum constitute a global Mackey functor. Consequently, these splittings give rise to the dissection of certain long exact homotopy group sequences into short exact sequences. In the case of the real and complex global Thom spectra, denoted $\mathbf{MO}$ and $\mathbf{MU}$, these splittings facilitate the determination of the regularity of various Euler classes associated with the tautological representations of $O(n)$ and $U(n)$.

Baryonic feedback effects reduce the weak lensing angular power spectrum at small scales. The uncertain shape and amplitude of this reduction represent a significant source of error for forthcoming cosmological weak lensing surveys like Euclid and LSST. In the initial installment of a two-part series, we employ simulations to create a Euclid-inspired tomographic dataset for the cosmic shear power spectrum, along with a corresponding covariance matrix, both adjusted for baryonic effects using the baryonification method by Schneider et al. (2019). Furthermore, we have constructed an emulator that produces rapid predictions of baryonic power suppression. This tool enables us to conduct a likelihood analysis inferring a standard $\Lambda$CDM cosmology, incorporating both cosmological and astrophysical parameters.

Spontaneous conversations in real-life environments, like those in child-centered recordings, are among the most difficult types of audio to process. However, developing speech processing models that cope with such diverse conditions is highly valuable for language development research, where the focus is on analyzing the amount and complexity of speech that children are exposed to and produce. It is also beneficial for the early detection of language issues and the assessment of treatment outcomes. In our paper, we introduce an open-source neural network designed to identify different types of audio segments: child vocalizations captured by the recording device worn by the child, utterances by other children, and speech by adult males and females. For this purpose, we compiled a varied set of child-centered corpora, totaling 260 hours of recordings spanning 10 different languages.

Density-based clustering hinges on connecting clusters with specific characteristics of the data's underlying probability distribution. This approach acknowledges an actual, albeit undetermined, population structure to contextualize the clustering task within a traditional inferential framework, where the notion of ideal population clustering corresponds to the partition created by the authentic density function. This method in its nonparametric form, often termed modal clustering, associates clusters with the areas influenced by the density function's peaks. In practice, this method necessitates a nonparametric density estimation, and crucially, choosing the correct degree of smoothing is essential as it affects the density's contour and, consequently, the potential modal configuration, to define the ultimate cluster division. In our study, we tackle the challenge of density estimation for modal clustering, examining it through the lens of asymptotic behavior.

The tails of diboson production at the LHC are highly sensitive to interference effects between Standard Model processes and higher-dimensional operators that suggest the presence of heavy, new physics. Nevertheless, helicity selection rules present in diboson scattering amplitudes act as a barrier, diminishing the expected interference contributions from dimension-six operators and resulting in the leading contributions to the overall diboson rate correction being negated. However, precise measurements of the azimuthal decay angles can restore visibility to this interference, thereby regaining sensitivity to those operators initially deemed non-interfering. Our detailed investigation into these phenomena reveals that uncertainties related to effective field theory, arising from higher-dimensional operators, are significantly mitigated by constructing an asymmetry variable. This variable, which arises solely due to non-interfering operators, effectively minimizes the influence of the interfering, higher-dimensional operators, relegating their effects to a level comparable to statistical errors in the measurement.

The pursuit of causal inference from observational data drives many analytical efforts in the health and social sciences. Nevertheless, the academic statistical community has traditionally viewed data analyses aimed at determining causality with skepticism. The emergence of "data science" as a discipline presents an unprecedented opportunity to reshape the understanding of data analysis in a way that inherently embraces causal inference from observational data. Building on prior work, we categorize the scientific endeavors of data science into three distinct types of tasks: descriptive, predictive, and counterfactual prediction, the latter of which encompasses causal inference. A clear delineation of these data science tasks is vital to outline the specific data, presumptions, and analytical techniques needed to effectively perform each task. We contend that the widespread misunderstandings about data science often stem from an inadequate explanation of how expertise in the subject matter plays a crucial role in the data analysis process.

The Weak Gravity Conjecture (WGC) asserts the necessity of superextremal particles for any consistent quantum gravity theory. Common understanding posits that these particles play a critical role in rendering extremal black holes either unstable or at best, marginally stable. The precise implications of their absence, however, remain unclear. This brief demonstrates that, within a generic Einstein quantum gravity framework in AdS spaces, the exact stability of extremal black branes conflicts with well-established quantum information theorems concerning entanglement entropy. To reconcile this discrepancy, we propose a nonperturbative formulation of the WGC, which converges with the familiar hypothesis in the regime of weak coupling. The reasoning presented is broad in scope, eschewing dependence on supersymmetry or any specific UV completion. It relies solely on the soundness of Einsteinian gravity, the principles of effective field theory, and the concept of holography.

Deciphering the emergence of unconventional superconductivity in strongly correlated two-dimensional (2D) systems with high critical temperatures remains a significant challenge in condensed matter physics. Ultracold 2D Fermi gases have been recognized as pristine and manipulable platforms for probing the effects of strong correlations and reduced dimensionality, yet direct evidence for superfluidity in these systems has been elusive. In this study, we confirm superfluidity in an ultracold 2D Fermi gas, evidenced by the absence of dissipation when a periodic potential is moved through the gas below a critical velocity v$_{\rm c}$. This velocity, v$_{\rm c}$, is measured across various interaction strengths, revealing a peak in the transitional regime where bosonic and fermionic superfluidity converge. Our findings effectively position ultracold Fermi gases as a formidable investigative tool for exploring the impact of reduced dimensionality on strongly correlated superfluid phenomena.

An ordinary differential equation (ODE) serves as a pivotal mathematical model across various fields, including climatology, bioinformatics, and chemical engineering, owing to its intuitive modeling capabilities. However, the widespread application of ODEs in modeling is often challenged by the lack of analytical solutions, complicating the process of deducing ODE parameters from empirical data. This issue is particularly pronounced in complex models teeming with numerous variables and parameters. To address this, the present paper introduces a Bayesian algorithm for ODE parameter estimation that is both rapid and precise, even in the context of parameter-rich models. The method simplifies an ODE model by recasting it into a state-space format derived from the equations of a numerical solver. By circumventing the need to calculate the full numerical solution during likelihood evaluations, it significantly accelerates the estimation process. The posterior distribution is then acquired via a Variational Bayes approach, employing the approximate Riemannian conjugate gradient method as detailed by Honkela et al.

Our investigation delves into the transport properties and the superconducting proximity effect within NSN junctions, which consist of a time-reversal symmetry-broken Weyl semimetal (WSM) in close contact with an $s$-wave superconductor. We discover that both the differential conductance and the induced pairing amplitudes are markedly influenced by the orientation of the junction in real space relative to the momentum space axis delineating the Weyl nodes. We pinpoint the impact of a chiral chemical potential—defined by the electron population difference between Weyl nodes of opposing chiralities—on the junction's transport properties. Notably, we detect a distinctive spin polarization in the Cooper pairs that are formed through Andreev reflection within the two WSM regions. This polarization exhibits an antiparallel alignment across the WSM regions and is exceedingly sensitive to both the chirality imbalance and the excitation energy.

Implanting metal ions into ceramics has proven to be an effective, controllable technique to customize the surface electrical conductivity of ceramic materials, with wide-ranging applications. This method is particularly valuable for managing the voltage gradient across high-voltage insulators, thus enhancing their capacity to handle increased operational voltage without the risk of surface flashover. Nevertheless, the long-term stability of the conductivity induced by this implantation raises concerns, especially when the implanted metal is prone to oxidation. In this study, we investigate the enduring behavior of surface conductivity in titanium-implanted alumina. Our findings reveal an initial conductivity reduction of up to 40% within the first few weeks post-implantation. Subsequently, the conductivity experiences a marginal decline of approximately 10% over the course of the following year.

We propose a new, Skyrme-like conserved current in the effective theory of pions and vector mesons, inspired by the concept of hidden local symmetry. The corresponding charge mirrors the skyrmion charge across all smooth configurations. Moreover, we identify singular configurations as n_f=1 baryons, which bear the charge of this new symmetry. Within this framework, vector mesons serve as Chern-Simons vector fields on the Quantum Hall droplet that constitutes the n_f=1 baryon. We suggest that this current accurately represents the baryon current at low energies. Our approach offers a cohesive understanding of both baryon types, facilitating their seamless transition from one to the other. Furthermore, the application of Chern-Simons dualities on the droplet can be viewed as stemming from a Seiberg-like duality that interchanges gluons with vector mesons.

Interfacial spin-orbit coupling in Josephson junctions presents a fascinating approach to integrating anomalous Hall effects with Josephson physics within a unified platform. Our theoretical investigation examines the influence of these combined effects on the transport properties of superconductor/ferromagnetic insulator/superconductor junctions. The transverse momentum dependence of Cooper pairs' skew tunneling across the spin-active interface of the ferromagnetic insulator generates significant transverse Hall supercurrents, which we term anomalous Josephson Hall effect currents. We have refined the Furusaki-Tsukada formula, originally devised to calculate conventional Josephson current flow, to assess the transverse current components, showing their magnitudes can be extensively tuned via the strength of the spin-orbit coupling or the superconducting phase difference throughout the junction. Moreover, as a definitive spectroscopic hallmark of Josephson junctions, distinct subgap bound states emerge in the vicinity of the interface.

Building on the insights from Jiménez, J. in Journal of Turbulence (2020), which emphasized the significance of dipoles in the dynamics of decaying two-dimensional turbulence alongside individual vortex cores, it has been determined that the kinetic energy in this flow predominantly resides in elongated currents. These currents result from the sequence of interconnected dipoles. The vortex population splits into two distinct groups: a set of small, swift-moving cores and a contrasting set of larger, more leisurely-moving ones that seemingly solidify within a gradually transforming 'crystal' structure. The movement patterns of these two groups differ greatly, with only the former exhibiting self-similarity. The latter group, which harbors the bulk of the flow's kinetic energy, gives rise to the dipoles and subsequent currents. The paper delves into the mechanisms that may contribute to the proliferation of this slower-moving component.

Continuous-time quantum walks (CTQWs) serve as a powerful framework for creating numerous quantum algorithms. Typically, the performance of quantum algorithms utilizing this model hinges on the quantum hitting time—the duration it takes for the quantum walk to locate a targeted vertex with considerable probability. In this article, we present refined upper bounds for the quantum hitting time, which are applicable to a variety of CTQW-dependent quantum algorithms. Specifically, we enhance the hitting time upper bound for the glued-trees problem by a polynomial factor, reducing it from $O(n^5)$ to $O(n^2\log n)$. Moreover, our techniques substantially boost the precision dependency in the performance of the CTQW-based algorithm by Chakraborty et al., which aims to identify a marked node in any ergodic, reversible Markov chain, achieving an exponential improvement.

Extreme Mass Ratio Inspirals (EMRIs) are categorized into dry and wet EMRIs, distinguished by their respective formation processes. Previously, dry EMRIs, also known as 'loss-cone' EMRIs, were thought to be the primary sources for the Laser Interferometer Space Antenna, originating mainly from multi-body scattering within the nuclear star cluster and through gravitational capture. In this letter, however, we present an alternative channel for EMRI formation: the wet EMRI channel, facilitated by the accretion flows surrounding the massive black holes (MBHs) at the centers of accreting galaxies. In this process, the accretion disk ensnares stellar-mass black holes initially on inclined orbits and subsequently guides their migration toward the MBH. This mechanism significantly elevates the EMRI formation rate in such galaxies, multiplying it by orders of magnitude.

When a new user registers on a website, we often lack any initial information about them – no interactions with items, no user profile, and no social connections with other users are established at that point. Despite this, it is essential for our recommender systems to engage these first-time visitors effectively, encouraging them to continue using the site and transition into active users. This challenge is known as the new user cold-start problem and is critical for a company's growth and sustainability. Current approaches to cold-start user recommendation typically require extra effort from the user, such as completing an interview process, or they rely on ancillary information, such as demographics, locations, and social networks. However, the willingness of users to participate in interviews is variable, and such additional information is often unavailable for new users.

Deep learning has successfully tackled a multitude of problems previously inaccessible to heuristic algorithms. It has carved a niche in the realm of wireless communications, despite current radio systems being highly sophisticated with optimal algorithms available for numerous operations. Gains have been realized by applying learning techniques to individual receiver components, yet an integrated approach—learning the entire receiver simultaneously—proves to be more effective. However, such an approach typically presents a complex nonlinear challenge, rendering the ideal solution impractical to execute. In response, we introduce a robust deep fully convolutional neural network, named deeprx, designed to process the entire reception pipeline, from the frequency domain signal to the decoding of uncoded bits, in compliance with 5G standards. To ensure precise channel estimation, we meticulously construct the neural network's input by integrating both data and pilot symbols in a strategic manner.

Mutation-based fuzzing typically begins with a collection of non-crashing seed inputs known as a corpus, which serves as a foundation for generating new inputs through mutation. Often, a corpus may comprise thousands of inputs with significant similarity, which can result in inefficient fuzzing efforts due to the exhaustive mutation of all available seeds. To mitigate this, fuzzers are equipped with distillation tools such as afl-cmin, which are designed to identify and retain only a minimal subset of seeds that activate the same spectrum of instrumentation data points as the entire corpus. It is generally accepted that reducing both the number of seeds and their cumulative size contributes to more effective fuzzing—a theory we systematically investigate. We share the outcomes from over 34 cpu-years of fuzzing using five different distillation methodologies to evaluate their effect on bug discovery in real-world software applications.

In this study, we explore multi-agent discrete-event systems under the constraint of partial observation. We categorize the agents into various groups, where each group's agents display analogous state transition structures, permitting a standardized template to be applied for relabeling purposes. Utilizing this template, we construct a scalable supervisor whose dimensions and computational demands remain constant irrespective of the number of agents, ensuring efficiency in scenarios of partial observation. Notably, this scalable supervisor maintains its configuration without the necessity of recalibration, regardless of the agents' fluctuating numbers within the system. Moreover, we extend our prior findings to systems with partial observation, establishing sufficient conditions to guarantee both the safety and the maximum allowance of system operations by the scalable and minimally restrictive supervisor at the template level. To demonstrate the effectiveness of our scalable supervisory synthesis approach, we include a practical example.

Electric Network Frequency (ENF) fluctuations serve as a potent instrument for multimedia forensics. We introduce an effective method for ENF estimation, leveraging temporal windowing combined with the Filter-Bank Capon spectral estimator. Utilizing Gohberg-Semencul factorization to account for the Toeplitz structure inherent in the covariance matrix enhances efficiency. Uniquely in the realm of ENF, this method incorporates a non-rectangular temporal window during the pre-spectral estimation phase. For swift matrix inversion, Krylov matrices are utilized. The proposed methodology surpasses current leading techniques in ENF estimation, particularly when applying a brief, one-second time window in power recordings. For speech recordings, it delivers results with remarkable accuracy and reduced time complexity.

The direpack package integrates a suite of advanced statistical dimension reduction techniques into the world of Python as a cohesive entity. These techniques fall into three main categories: projection pursuit-based dimension reduction, sufficient dimension reduction, and robust M estimators for dimension reduction. Additionally, it provides a range of regularized regression estimators that leverage these lower-dimensional spaces, from traditional principal component regression to sparse partial robust M regression. The package further offers an assortment of both classical and robust pre-processing tools, including generalized spatial signs, along with specialized plotting features and cross-validation utilities. Written in alignment with the scikit-learn API, direpack allows its estimators to be seamlessly incorporated into statistical and machine learning pipelines within that ecosystem.

Nonlinear fluorescence emission is extensively utilized for high spatial resolution optical imaging. In this study, we investigated the anomalous saturation effect of the nitrogen vacancy defect in diamond on fluorescence. We noted a decrease in fluorescence under high-power laser excitation, which intensified the nonlinearity of the emission and altered the fluorescence image’s spatial frequency distribution. A differential excitation protocol allowed us to isolate high spatial frequency information. By adjusting the excitation laser's power, we successfully enhanced the spatial resolution of imaging by approximately 1.6-fold relative to confocal microscopy. The experimental setup's simplicity, along with streamlined data processing, suggests that this technique has the potential to significantly improve spatial resolution in applications such as sensing and biological labeling that employ defects in solid materials.

When random effects are correlated with variables from the sample design, the standard practice of using individual survey weights—which are inversely related to the probability of selection for the survey—to establish a pseudo-likelihood, fails to yield unbiased inferences as the sample size grows. To address this issue, we have developed a weight-exponentiated formulation for the distribution of random effects, ensuring unbiased inference when determining the hyperparameters associated with these effects. Unlike frequentist methods that depend on numerical integration, our Bayesian technique guarantees unbiased estimation that reflects the sampling design distribution and remains consistent with the underlying population distribution. Through simulations and an empirical example involving a business establishment survey, we showcase our method's effectiveness across various model specifications and sample designs. This research not only marks a culmination of recent advancements that integrate conventional survey estimation techniques with Bayesian modeling, but it also builds a much-needed bridge between these two historically distinct sub-disciplines.

Materials with low symmetry in two dimensions, including monolayers of ReS$_2$ and ReSe$_2$, black phosphorus, Group-IV monochalcogenides, and borophene, exhibit more intricate atomic structures compared to the honeycomb patterns found in graphene, hexagonal boron nitride, and transition metal dichalcogenides. These materials, with their diminished symmetry, lead to diverse and uneven responses in electron behavior, optical characteristics, valley physics, and spin dynamics. Additionally, they possess unique qualities such as ferroelasticity, ferroelectricity, magnetism, spin-wave phenomena, sizeable nonlinear optical properties, photogalvanic effects, and even superconductivity. Low symmetry also facilitates the emergence of unconventional electronic topological attributes, nonlinear elasticity, and structural phase transitions. The special topic "Beyond Graphene: Low-Symmetry and Anisotropic 2D Materials" was curated to showcase recent advancements, both experimental and theoretical, in the study of these novel materials.

The orientational dynamics of a comb-shaped nematic polymer, featuring both mesogenic and functional side groups, were investigated in the isotropic phase through Kerr effect measurements and dielectric spectroscopy. This study revealed, for the first time, that the relaxation of electric birefringence in such mesogenic polymers—a contrast to their low-molecular-weight counterparts—can be described by a combination of several exponential processes, among which two are particularly critical. These principal processes sequentially dominate over a temperature interval of approximately fifty degrees, following the nematic-to-isotropic phase transition. Furthermore, dielectric spectroscopy enabled the identification of two distinct orientational relaxation mechanisms: one attributable to the rotation of mesogenic side groups and the other linked to the motion of the polymer's main chain segments.

Deep hashing techniques have proven to be highly accurate and efficient for large-scale image retrieval tasks. A key concern in deep hashing is the optimization of discrete hash bits. Typically, these methods employ an activation function such as $\operatorname{sigmoid}(\cdot)$ or $\operatorname{tanh}(\cdot)$, and aim to minimize quantization loss to achieve discrete value approximation. However, this approach can result in an increasing number of hash bits becoming irreversibly trapped in the saturated regions of the activation functions, a problem we refer to as the "dead bits problem" (DBP). Additionally, the current quantization loss exacerbates the DBP. To mitigate this issue, we introduce a straightforward yet potent gradient amplifier, which is applied prior to the activation functions, offering a solution to alleviate the DBP.

We examine the phenomenology of a hypercharge-zero SU(2) triplet scalar, postulated to play a role in a two-step electroweak symmetry breaking process. Our analysis covers scenarios in which the triplets are either stable, contributing to dark matter density, or unstable, decaying through interactions with the Standard Model Higgs boson. The stability hypothesis of the triplets faces stringent constraints from disappearing charged track searches at the LHC and from dark matter direct detection experiments. Conversely, the decay scenario is limited by outcomes from multilepton collider searches. Our results indicate that a two-step electroweak phase transition featuring a stable triplet with a negative quadratic term is incompatible with direct detection experiments. Meanwhile, any unstable triplet lighter than 230 GeV is excluded with a 95% confidence level.

This study demonstrates that the eccentric debris rings observed around the stars Fomalhaut and HD 202628 are more constricted than predicted by the conventional model of planetary perturbations, often referred to as "pericenter glow". This prevalent model suggests a belt of planetesimals starting as a circular and condensed ring at a semi-major axis $a$ that, following the dispersal of the gas disc, undergoes an increase in eccentricity to $e_f$ due to secular perturbations from an eccentric planet, thereby forming a belt with a width of $2ae_f$. A slight adjustment to this model can account for thinner belts if the planetesimals already possess an initial eccentricity, potentially imparted by planetary disturbances during the earlier, gas-rich stage of the protoplanetary disk. Nonetheless, this initial eccentricity could also stem from instabilities that amplify the disk's eccentricity, eliminating the need for planetary influences.

An electron is commonly understood to possess a singular type of kinetic energy. However, could it harbor additional kinds given its spin and charge, or through the excitation of other electrons? In one-dimensional (1D) systems, the Tomonaga-Luttinger liquid (TLL) model proficiently describes the physics of interacting electrons at low energies. Nevertheless, little experimental evidence exists beyond this linear regime. In this context, we present findings from our measurements of many-body modes in 1D gated wires, utilizing tunneling spectroscopy. Our observations reveal two distinct Fermi seas at elevated energies, corresponding to spin and charge excitations. Additionally, we have detected the emergence of three novel 1D 'replica' modes that intensify as the wire length decreases. By varying the degree of 1D inter-subband screening by over 45%, we can manipulate the effective interaction strength within the wires.

The ongoing unraveling of the Milky Way's assembly history is being propelled by insights from the Gaia mission. Similarly, it is posited that our galaxy's globular cluster system has undergone a complex developmental trajectory. The aim of our study is to delineate this trajectory by investigating the association between the globular clusters and the Milky Way's documented mergers. To achieve this, we amalgamated Gaia's kinematic data for the majority of galactic clusters with an unparalleled sample of cluster ages, refined to address any systematic discrepancies. Our analysis focused on the clusters' dynamical characteristics, especially within the realm of integrals of motion, to pinpoint clusters sharing a common provenance. The results indicate that approximately 40% of the clusters appear to have originated within the galaxy itself.

Estimating the intrinsic dimension of a dataset is a crucial step in numerous dimensionality reduction strategies. This article presents intrinsic, an R package dedicated to providing novel, cutting-edge likelihood-based estimators for pinpointing a dataset's intrinsic dimension. Specifically, the package incorporates methods such as two-nn, GRIDE, and HALIGO. Intrinsic offers user-friendly, high-level functions supported by a suite of efficient, underlying routines to make these advanced estimations readily available. The package categorizes the models into homogeneous and heterogeneous intrinsic dimension estimators. The two-nn and GRIDE models, encompassed in the first category, permit inference within both frequentist and Bayesian frameworks through their respective functions. Meanwhile, the second category features HALIGO, a Bayesian mixture model served by an effective Gibbs sampler for estimation.

Spintronic nanodevices exhibit ultrafast nonlinear dynamics with recurrence on a nanosecond scale, showing great promise for advancing spintronic reservoir computing (RC) systems. In this context, we proposed and modeled two physical RC systems: one utilizing a single magnetic skyrmion memristor (MSM) for image classification tasks and the other employing 24 spin-torque nano-oscillators (STNOs) for predicting nonlinear dynamic systems. Our micromagnetic simulation results reveal that the nonlinear responses of MSM and STNO when stimulated by current pulses enable the MSM-based RC system to achieve exceptional image classification performance, as evidenced by its ability to accurately recognize handwritten digits. Furthermore, the RC system comprising 24 STNOs demonstrates proficiency in addressing complex, unknown nonlinear dynamics, as confirmed through applications involving a second-order nonlinear dynamic system and the NARMA10 benchmark tasks.

Ranking algorithms are pivotal in shaping user experiences on diverse online platforms, from search engines to recommendation systems. In this paper, we uncover a perplexing outcome inherent to popularity-driven ranking systems: a disproportionate amount of traffic is garnered by a small number of items sharing a common signal. This "few-get-richer" phenomenon becomes especially pronounced in situations where items fall into a limited number of categories (for example, news sources with left- or right-leaning biases) and are sorted by their popularity metrics. We reveal through analytical evidence that this effect arises as individuals predominantly select items at the top of the list, while maintaining varied preferences for different item categories. Through simulations, we explore how variations in the environment and user behavior modulate the intensity of this effect. Additionally, we conduct online experiments with human participants to empirically validate our theoretical predictions. Our research sheds light on critical factors influencing the dissemination of misinformation, offering significant insights into its prevention.

Weight pruning is recognized as an effective technique to reduce redundancy in deep neural networks (DNNs), leading to faster performance across various platforms. However, most pruning methods present a compromise between model accuracy and performance, often resulting in diminished inference precision and suboptimal acceleration on devices. To address this issue, we present a novel approach involving pattern-based sparsity, which integrates both pattern and connectivity sparsity, achieving high accuracy while remaining conducive to hardware implementation. Our carefully crafted patterns enable our pruning method to consistently enhance accuracy and improve feature extraction across diverse DNN architectures and datasets. Additionally, our pattern-aware pruning framework facilitates the extraction of a pattern library, selection of patterns, and concurrent pruning of pattern, connectivity, and weight training. This new facet of pattern-based sparsity seamlessly integrates with compiler optimizations, optimizing DNN execution efficiency on mobile devices.

A difference-in-differences analysis is susceptible to bias when the control group significantly diverges from the treated group, particularly when historical events impact the groups differently. To mitigate this, we refined our control group by matching a subset of it to the treated group, leading to a potential reduction in bias. This method's effectiveness was assessed through simulation studies. Specifically, we examined the impact of mountaintop removal mining (MRM) on mortality rates by employing a difference-in-differences approach that accounted for the MRM increase post the 1990 Clean Air Act Amendments. By creating a more tightly matched control group for the analysis of MRM's effect on mortality, we identified a 95% confidence interval that includes a range of possible outcomes, from significant negative effects to negligible or slight positive effects.

When creating models to encapsulate clinical data for simulation purposes, it's important to assess their ability to accurately reflect the data. This verification is often conducted using visual predictive checks (VPCs). These checks involve: (1) simulating the original study several times using the model being tested, (2) calculating relevant estimates for each simulation, and (3) comparing the distribution of these simulated estimates with that of the original study. As a general approach, this procedure is easy to implement. In this context, we focus on its application to time-to-event data, specifically addressing the scenario where a time-dependent covariate is either unknown or cannot be reliably estimated post-event.

This paragraph presents novel concepts, perspectives, and challenges associated with measuring and controlling an open quantum system through sequential approaches. We explore how protocols that combine repeated quantum measurements with dynamical decoupling control pulses can enable us to (i) confine and shield quantum dynamics from decoherence, aligning with Zeno physics; (ii) analytically calculate the likelihood of transferring a quantum system into a desired quantum state through stochastic sequential measurements; and (iii) optimally deduce the spectral density of environmental noise by orthogonalizing filter functions in the frequency domain for the purpose of fine-tuning the quantum sensor. Successfully accomplishing these objectives will improve our ability to monitor and control open quantum systems, thereby advancing quantum science and technology.

Palms damp with sweat, heart pounding, and stomach twisted into knots. Calling for help isn't an option; your throat is too constricted to breathe, let alone shout, and the embarrassment feels intolerable. Yet, you're not facing a lurking beast; you're confronting the daunting task of public speaking, which some consider a fate worse than death. After all, in death, you feel nothing, but at a podium, every ounce of stage fright courses through you. However, we have all, at some time, needed to address an audience, so finding a way to overcome this fear is essential. To begin, it's crucial to understand what stage fright really is. We are inherently social creatures, preoccupied with our societal standing, and public speaking poses a risk to our perceived image. Pre-speech worries often manifest as nagging thoughts: "What if I'm terrible? What if they think I'm an idiot?"

It's difficult to imagine someone possessing a singular interest in life, one that they wish to pursue exclusively. In the modern employment landscape, approximately 15 percent of American workers are not engaged in traditional full-time jobs; instead, they are employed part-time, as contractors, or on a temporary basis. "Side hustle" has emerged as a term that aptly encapsulates this dynamic, reflecting how individuals piece together various engagements to earn their livelihood. The phrase "side hustle" is rooted in vernacular from prominent African American publications in the 1920s, where "hustle" often suggested an illicit scheme. By the 1950s, these outlets expanded its usage to encompass legitimate forms of work as well. Notably, a side hustle differs from a second job in that the latter is usually borne out of financial necessity, whereas a side hustle might not be.

Two contrasting twin domes encapsulate divergent design philosophies. The first comprises thousands of interlocking steel components, while the second unfurls from a singular silk thread. Synthetic construction contrasts with organic growth. One dome dominates its landscape, while the second harmoniously emerges from it. The first serves nature, while the second is an embodiment of her craftsmanship. Michelangelo once professed that within uncarved marble, he perceived figures yearning for release. His solitary tool, the chisel, liberated those forms. Yet, unlike marble sculptures, living organisms do not arise from the strike of a chisel; they burgeon from within. Within our cellular matrix resides the intricate blueprint necessary for each cell's function and duplication. The tools we wield inevitably shape outcomes. Since the dawn of the Industrial Revolution, the design realm has been governed by the demands of manufacturing and the drive for mass production.
